text:
Nested template support in Collection<T> and Map<K, V>
Currently, T (or K / V) is consider a type directly, but not as a potentially nested type, for example List<List<Product>>.  In this example, T at the outer level is List<Product>.  Need to handle support for unlimited nesting within template parameters, in the code that uses the template parameters to infer Collection or Map object types, when type is not set within the Collection or Map contents.

text:
There is a new 'optionalArg' Map for the public JsonWriter APIs.  What this allows, is for new functionality to be added, without changing the JsonWriter's API.

Currently, you can set the key 'DATE_FORMAT' (JsonWriter.DATE_FORMAT) and then set the value of it to a date format String.  If this is found, this will be used to write out java.util.Dates. 

Also, you can set the value JsonWriter.TYPE to 'true' and it will force @type's to be written out (not recommended, as it will significantly increase the size of the JSON stream).  This was added for the rare case where the recipient needs all @type information but cannot infer it (rare occurrence - it was a JBoss rule engine user).

In the future, other such 'hints' will be added to JsonWriter as required.  In those cases, JsonWriter will have a public String final key that can be used to place the value into the optionalArgs Map.  If you look at the internal _args member variable, and where that is accessed, that is where JsonWriter takes into account the values set into this optionalArgs map.

text:
I initially tried this, but had problems with it. Some of the difficulties are the fact that Maps in Java can have non-String keys, and secondly, I believe there was a forward reference issue.  

If you are serializing between Java and Java, this is a non issue.  If you are serializing to Javascript, then you may be scratching your head, asking what you do with the @keys and @items, right?  There is Javascript code that walks the object graph after it is loaded on the Javascript side, and recreates the Javascript maps.  This is done after resolveRefs(), which does the @id/@ref substitution.  

Also, there is Javascript code that replaces 'pointers' with @id/@ref pairs on the outbound side, so that proper graph shape is maintained when being sent to the server.  Think of it like 'stringify()' plus it properly handles cycles.  With this Javascript code (and json-io), full Java object graphs can be serialized and deserialized back-n-forth without any issues.

Finally, there is a Spring MessageConverter class that plus into Spring MVC so that json-io is the serialization provider (we were using Jackson, but with json-io we have full graph marshaling and it handles collection fields better).

Back to your original point, the method you mention is where the change would be made to attempt to write out the graph as pairs of keys (remember these can be complex graphs) and values.  If you take a stab at making this change to JsonWriter and get it writing Maps this way correctly (testing with Lists, Maps, and other narly objects as the key), the JsonReader change should be manageable.

I failed to mention that the Javascript code that substitutes @keys/@items, does the cycle aware stringify(), and the json-io MessageConverter are not yet checked in.  Expect those to be added within the next month or so.  We are fine tuning these (user crowland has written the @keys/@items substituion code and the Message converter, and another user has written in the cycle aware serialization).  I am getting these package up so that json-io earn the top spot as the best JSON serializer.

json-io has a good Android following because it is a very small library with no external dependencies, and they can use Java on the client, allowing them to send / receive any graphs to the device.

Dave,

Now I see what you were talking about.  I think I misunderstood your
question.  I got ahead of myself on a comment and have yet to check in the
work (field filtering) that I mention in the comment.  I will remove that
from the comment for now.

Field fitlering is coming soon.  PUBLIC, ALL_BUT_TRANSIENT, ALL, and a
FieldFilter that you write and associate to a class, allowing your class to
selectively decide what fields get serialized.  This will be pretty easy to
implement and further increases json-io's power.

Best regards,
John

text:
Rather than make @pairs an [] of String key to {} (object), you might want to try this instead:

```
"@pairs":[[key0, value0], [key1, value1], ... [key-n, value-n]]
```

This would at least allow for non-strings as keys.  This approach would keep the key and associated value 'near' each other.  On the reader side, it would have to pull apart these fixed, 2-element key/value arrays and make Map entries for each.

If I recall correctly, I think I tried this in the past, however, it still requires 'remapping' when it hits the Javascript side.  In addition, I was able to treat the @keys as a list and @items as a list, and therefore writing maps was trivial as the collection writer and collection entry writer code is used on these portions of map.  If I had gone with the fixed, 2-element approach above, the map writer would require more code.  Since this effort still does not give you a Javascript map the way you are thinking of it (without Javascript code that converts it), I scuttled the effort.

Since JSON does not allow Object keys to be non-Strings, there is no solution that I can think of that can be done that will not require the Javascript helper code to rebuild the maps.

text:
In version 1.10.0 of java-util, DeepEquals.deepEquals() no longer takes the Map or Collection type into consideration when comparing, other than not allowing the sorted versus non-sorted types to be compared.

For example, it is valid to compare a HashMap to ConcurrentHashMap, but not a HashMap and a TreeMap - that will still return false.  The same holds for the Collection types.

Serialized simple string can not be deserialized by JsonReader
A String will be serialized fine as simple String:
String strJson = JsonWriter.objectToJson("5");
 =>  "5"

But the json reader can not read this vice versa, it throws an Exception
String strClone = (String) JsonReader.jsonToJava(strJson);

Same Exception when formatting the string with
String strBeauty = JsonWriter.formatJson(strJson);

java.io.IOException: Input is invalid JSON; does not start with '{' or '[', c=34
Last read: "
line: 1, col: 2
    at com.cedarsoftware.util.io.JsonReader.error(JsonReader.java:3203)
    at com.cedarsoftware.util.io.JsonReader.readJsonObject(JsonReader.java:2213)
    at com.cedarsoftware.util.io.JsonReader.readObject(JsonReader.java:1161)
    at com.cedarsoftware.util.io.JsonReader.jsonToJava(JsonReader.java:1085)

Thus, we have to make a workaround for serializing/deserializing simple Strings. We are using json-io 2.6.1. We would be pleased if this could be fixed! Thanks a lot for this fine piece of work.

text:
Feature request: add an optional fallback type parameter for the toplevel json container to JsonReader.jsonToJava(json);
We give the possibility to specify http get parameters also as json strings, to allow class objects as parameter types for the web interfaces also.

The problem is, by using json-io, specifying @type in the json string is mandatory for deserialization, right? Thus, the users have to specify it, which is not so nice (for the return values its fine of course, but for parameters?)

I love the way json-io deals with types, for me, it is the best solution to support polymorphism I have seen in such a library. Nevertheless, in this case, the underlying type of the parameter normally not changes - it should be transparent for the (e.g. javascript) user of the interface who creates the json, and clear for the server.

Is it possible to add another method to JsonReader.jsonToJava(String json, Class toplevelFallbackType) - where toplevelFallbackType could be also String, Type, etc. of course.
This parameter would then be used as fallback if the @type was not specified in the toplevel json object.
I know this would not work with polymorphism, but it would help us a lot and would be maybe a nice enhanchement of json-ios functionality:)

Thanks and best regards

Christian

...as far as I found a solution for reading those json-Strings without toplevel type, it is a bit hard to create those with json-io. I did so with Collections and Arrays, by subclassing JsonWriter, adding a method write(Object obj, boolean showTopLevelType). This method simply adds the possibility to specify the 'showType' parameter in the writeImpl invocation - everything else is identical to the origin write(Object obj) method.
Sadly, I had to use forbidden reflection API to make this invocations in the subclass, because some fields and methods are declared private.
For this, I want to ask whether these elements of JsonWriter could be declared protected, to enable better subclassing of JsonWriter:
- traceReferences
- _objVisited
- writeImpl
- _objsReferenced
- _args

Thanks a lot

text:
The only two (2) characters that valid JSON can begin with are { or [.  In otherwords, an Object or an Array.  It is not valid JSON to just have a String.  Although it can be written, it cannot be read.  See the BNF diagram on http://json.org .

Here's an option.  Put your String in an Object[] and then send that.  When you read it, pull the String out of the Object[](it would be the first entry in the array).  This should at least get you on the right path.

text:
I appreciate the suggestion and on the surface it looks like it would work.  However, that is not the case.  Perhaps I should rename the method to make this more clear.  convertParsedMapsToJava() internally calls convertMapsToObjects(). Internally, this method takes a different path based on the _noObjects flag.  

So although the outer method is called convertParsedMapsToJava() perhaps it should be called convertParsedMapsToJavaOrMaps().  I don't like the 'OR' in the method name.  

After the JSON parser has run (it is a Finite State Machine FSM parser), there is still work to be.  For example, forward references need to be patched, and some work is also done in terms of converting Arrays, Collections, Maps, and some work on primitives.  All the methods that end in "Obj()" are the versions that traverse the parsed model and make the cleaned up Map of Maps representation.  This "cleaned up" Map of Maps representation can be passed back to the JsonWriter, and you will get JSON written that will look like it came from the original Java objects!

This is important, because it allows a system to read JSON in generically, parse it into a Graph structure, then work on it, and then write it back out, without ever requiring the code to have the Java classes loaded for which the JSON represents.

type is not mandetory to be specified in the json there are many circumstances where you can leave it out in the case of any field of an object the type parameter can be left off if the value associated to the field is the exact same type of the field usually the case when the json reader encounters json data without the type it looks at the field of the object and instantiates the object as the field type in that case where this does not work is when the field is an abstract class or interface there is special handling for the collection classes intelligent collection and map types are used type is also required when the field type is a superclass of the actual type written for example if you a class person and employee is derived from person if the field type is person but it is polymorphically pointing to an employee and the type is not written then the jsonreader cannot instantiate the class as an employee as it does not know that what to instantiate the best it could do is instantiate a person if person is concrete then it will instantiate it as person and the employee fields would be dropped not desired jsonwriter allows compares the instance type to the field type and does not write the type out in these cases so that the resulting json is smaller another case where type can be dropped is when you have a specific array type an employee of employee objects in this case the type if missing on the employee objects inside the array will be inferred from the type of the array however if the array was an object then it cannot make this inference jsonwriter compares the objects inside an array when writing them and drops the type in this case to make the resulting json smaller type can be left off of object of strings object of longs object of booleans object of doubles in all those cases it can infer the type furthermore these can be placed into the json as their native types as opposed to json objects in this case jsonwriter special handles these types so that they are written as json primitives long double string boolean

text:
I have found a solution in my scenario, I simply special handle the simple datatypes. I need this, because our service interfaces are used by both javascript users, and a special client generating library, which needs to deserialize everything that was serialized by the server formerly.

I checked the standard and you are right, in old versions of json it was the case, that a valid json text is only an object or an array. Don't know when exactly they changed this, but it's mentioned in the current rfc explicitly:
http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7159
http://tools.ietf.org/pdf/rfc7159.pdf
2. JSON Grammar (pdf page 4) "A JSON text is a serialized value. Note that certain previous
specifications of JSON constrained a JSON text to be an object or an array."
Also in the examples for valid json (page 13):
Here are three small JSON texts containing only values:
"Hello world!"
42
true

At the beginning of the rfc they mentioned:
" This document updates RFC4627, which describes JSON and registers the media type "application/json"."

"In the years since the publication of RFC 4627, JSON has found very wide use. This experience has revealed certain patterns, which, while allowed by its specifications, have caused interoperability problems.
Also, a small number of errata have been reported (see RFC Errata IDs 607 and 3607).
This document’s goal is to apply the errata, remove inconsistencies with other specifications of JSON, and highlight practices that can lead to interoperability problems."

text:
In Java, not Javascript, Map keys can be non-Strings.  For example, you
could have a Set as a key, or a Date, an Employee class, etc.  Because of
that, you cannot assume the key is a String.  The approach taken by json-io
allows ANY Java Map to be written to JSON and then re-read back in.
 Additionally, we have a Javascript function that will substitute the @keys
and @items after the JSON is read, so that even complex Maps from Java can
be read in Javascript.

On Tue, Jul 15, 2014 at 9:16 AM, reuschling notifications@github.com
wrote:

> In Javascript it is easy and straight forward to use a json string as
> associative array with just a single line of code, if it is in the notation
> 
> {
>    key0=val0;
>    key1=val1;
> }
> 
> Thus, it is perfect to deal with json generated by json-io out of java
> bean or pojo like Objects. I am wondering about why the generated json is
> different if the input is a java Map. Sadly, the generated json looks like
> this:
> 
> {
>  "@keys":[
>     "key0",
>     "key1"
>   ],
>   "@items":[
>     "val0",
>     "val1"
>   ]
> }
> 
> This is hard to read by humans as with more entries, it's not clear which
> value is associated with a key. It's hard to use programatically, since
> it's 'somehow special'. Last but not least, it's different to other json
> serializing libraries, which makes it hart for both server and client code
> to switch if you want to enjoy the advantages of json-io.
> 
> Is there a need for this additional syntax? I would ask for a feature
> request, or a hint how I can achieve the default json object associative
> syntax also for maps (maybe with a custom writer/reader).
>

text:
Ludek, I have created a 2.7.5 version of json-io which fixes the
ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.  I added test with a multi-template class
that use two fields of one template type, and one of the other.  The test
now passes.  The ArrayIndexOutOfBounds exception will no longer occur,
however, I still have some work to do to perfect handling the associated
template variable to the associated value.  What I have works pretty good,
and works in many cases you would not expect it to, because the type can be
figured out later.  Let me know if you have any further issues related to
template support.

text: The optionalArg TYPE parameter was just added in json-io 4.0.1 which allows the @type to be completely turned off.  This will create JSON that can be sent to Javascript, however, the created JSON may often not be properly reconstructed as a Java graph.  The option does add utility, for instance, sending JSON to a non-Java destination.

text: Francis, check out the code in my final fix.  Transient fields cannot be entirely skipped - if a field specifier map is used for the class, and the transient field is listed, then the transient field must be traced.  It is a slight modification to the code you submitted.  That fix (and a new test to ensure it is working correctly) was released in 4.1.8.

text: This could have been resolved using json-io's feature that allows you to assign an 'instantiator' to a given Class.  In this case, you would have created (in your code) an instantiator and associated it to EnumSet.class.  However, since EnumSet is a JDK class, it does belong in json-io.  I am letting you know this for future reference, assignInstantiator() will allow you to get past any constructor that is difficult to instantiate past the tricks that json-io tries.

text:
Empty EnumSet can't be used after being deserialized
Adding these lines to the end of TestSet.testSet() shows the problem.

``````
  ```
``````

  testSet._enumSet.remove(ManySets.EnumValues.E1);
        testSet._enumSet.remove(ManySets.EnumValues.E2);
        testSet._enumSet.remove(ManySets.EnumValues.E3);
        json = TestUtil.getJsonString(testSet)
        testSet = (ManySets) TestUtil.readJsonObject(json)
        testSet._enumSet.add(ManySets.EnumValues.E1);

```

The problem is the elementType is null when the EnumSet is deserialized, and then it cannot be used to add values. The elementType needs to be retained during the serialization/deserialization process and it's not.
```

A pull request will be provided.

text:
Provide a means of overriding the writing of an object
Currently the custom writer support does not allow you to simple add a field and then write the current object normally. You can write a child object, but not the current one.

A pull request will be provided.
clean: provide a means of overriding the writing of an object currently the custom writer support does not allow you to simple add a field and then write the current object normally you can write a child object but not the current one a pull request will be provided

text:
Provide a means of automatically reading an object with a custom reader
Currently the custom reader mechanism does not allow you to automatically read the current object, it has to be done entirely manually.

The use case for this and https://github.com/jdereg/json-io/issues/75 is to be able to add a single field to the serialized output of certain objects (to track a version number), but otherwise read and write the object automatically and normally.

A pull request will be provided.

text:
FIELD_SPECIFIERS does not allow subclasses field to be serialized
Hello,
Here is the documentation for FIELD_SPECIFIER map option for serializing objects
`// Set value to a Map<Class, List<String>> which will be used to control which fields on a class are output`
So what I understand from this is that it will only specify the field for given class to be serialized but implicitly means that subclasses fields shall be serialized.
But this is not the case.
here is the test case that show the opposite.

```
    @Test
    void testExternalFieldSpecifierInheritance()
    {
        Map<Class, List<String>> fieldSpecifiers = [(PainfulToSerialize.class):['name']]
        MorePainfulToSerialize painful = new MorePainfulToSerialize()
        painful.name = "Android rocks"
        painful.age = 50;

        def args = [(JsonWriter.FIELD_SPECIFIERS):fieldSpecifiers]
        String json = JsonWriter.objectToJson(painful, args)
        Map check = (Map) JsonReader.jsonToJava(json, [(JsonReader.USE_MAPS):true] as Map)
        assertTrue(check.size() == 1)
        assertTrue(check.containsKey("name"))
```

here I would expect the MorePainfulToSerialize.age to be serialized because we only specified the _name_ field for the parent class PainfulToSerialize.
So now if you specify a FIELD_SPECIFIERS for a given class, all fields that are added in subclasses will never be serialized which seems strange and make this feature not very useful I think.

text:
add a backlist of field not to be serialized
if we have an object that has fields not to be serialized in certain cases, which means we cannot use transient for this, there is not way to specify this.
I thought I could be using the FIELD_SPECIFIERS to specify  a white list of field thus removing the fields from this list but there is an issue with subclasses that does not allow this for subclasses ( see #78 ).
SO what would be great is to have a black list of field not be serialized.
I'll try to create a PR for this.

text:
JLBH - Support throughput < 1 operation / s
I'd like to use JLBH for benchmarking bulk operations which may take more than 1 second to complete. In my case they take around  5 seconds, so want to specify a target throughput of less than 1/5 or 0.2 operations / second. However, the signature `JLBHOptions#throughput(int)` effectively prohibits target throughput rates of less than 1 operation / s. 

Are you open to support smaller target throughput rates? I could imagine an overloaded version with the signature `JLBHOptions#throughput(int, TimeUnit)` to specify the throughput per time unit and the default would be `TimeUnit.SECONDS`.

text:
I did include your change to allow RMI support.

The 'Serializable' interface is old-school imho.  Using a serializer like json-io (one of my other projects), gson, etc. you can serialize any Java object, not Java classes that have to be 'pre-marked' with a marker interface (anti-pattern).  I realize you may be in a situation where you have to use ObjectInputStream / ObjectOutputStream.  If you do not have to use them, then definitely take a look at a JSON based serializer like json-io or gson.

text:
ClassLookup deprecation
The ClassLookup class has recently been marked as @Deprecated, however there is no explanation or documentation on what to use as an alternative. One might think they could use ClassAliasPool directly, but it has no public constructor, so it is unclear how to migrate away from the deprecated class.
clean: classlookup deprecation the classlookup class has recently been marked as deprecated however there is no explanation or documentation on what to use as an alternative one might think they could use classaliaspool directly but it has no public constructor so it is unclear how to migrate away from the deprecated class

text:
ClassAliasPool.addAlias() causes name collisions and deserialization failure
The `addAlias` method uses `Class.getSimpleName()`, which is far from unique. Especially considering inner classes and enums which often use the same name (e.g. 'Type') and are supposed to be distinguished by the containing class name. This causes serialization/deserialization to fail due to a mixup between classes with the same simple name (e.g. said enums).

FWIW, as a workaround we use something like
`cls.getName().replaceAll("(\\w)\\w*\\.", "$1").replace('$', '.')` which has more chances of being unique, yet is still pretty short, along with the overloaded `addAlias` that takes a name per class. Maybe you can use a similar default instead of the class simple name.

text:
I'm not sure what other examples you mean - I specified one in the original description. It takes the first letter of each part of the package name, concatenates them with the top-level class name, and for inner classes adds a period and the inner class name. Not 100% unique but much closer to it in practice than just the simple class name.

As for naming inner classes, perhaps it's a matter of taste, but I disagree. It makes sense to have enums such as Asset.TYPE and User.TYPE in different classes. Much cleaner than a redundant Asset.ASSET_TYPE and User.USER_TYPE or something like that... for the same reason I would think it's redundant to have a User.userId field rather than User.id. I also see no problem with having the same top-level class name used in different packages - there is no need to duplicate the name of the package in the name of the class, or pick a sub-optimal class name just because some other package has a class with the desired name imho.

Again, this may be a matter of taste, but in any case it does happen in practice so the class-handling code should probably deal with it properly.

text:
The aliases on apply to classes rather than fields.

So you could have

class User {
    class Type {
    }
}

and

class Asset {
    class Type {
    }
}

However, I would prefer to have a UserType and AssetType. esp as there is
already a built in Type interface.

In many cases the default pattern isn't suitable so you can add your own
alias such as

ClassAliasPool.CLASS_ALIASES.addAlias(ByteStore.class, "!binary");

ᐧ

text:
I understand aliases do not apply to fields, I was just making a point about naming conventions (the rational behind naming members without redundancy is the same, whether they are fields, enums or inner classes). 

By the way, as an anecdote, I see  6 different top-level Type classes in different packages in the java.* core namespace... so even for top-level classes it seems to be standard practice to use the same names in different places. All the more reason to properly support this.

I do add custom aliases using the addAlias overload, as I mentioned originally - using the naming scheme in the code snippet I quoted. I was just suggesting maybe you should use something like that as a better default rather than getSimpleName, since the latter has a much higher chance of collisions in practice. This is what this issue is about.

I see your point and this would reduce collisions but at the cost of making
the aliases more cryptic.

One of the uses for alias is moving classes between packages or renaming
them and still being able to deserialize data written earlier of by a
system with an older version of the code.
ᐧ

text:
StringUtils.extractChars can be inefficient in java9+ runtimes
`StringUtils.extractChars` currently returns a `char[]`; since java9, strings can be represented as ascii bytes, so a conversion is required between `byte[]` and `char[]`.

Current implementation allocates a new `char[]` and performs a per-byte copy.

Refers to #15

text:
I think we'll want to maintain support for both java 8 & java 9 on the same master branch, rather than having multiple branches.

I've committed changes to Chronicle-Core that allow it to build on java 9 without any special modifications. The java 9-specific code is hidden behind `Jvm.isJava9Plus()`.

Because of the need to maintain API compatibility between different libraries, it's going to be necessary to use existing APIs such as `StringUtils.extractChars` in Chronicle-Bytes, etc. In future, these may be special-cased for performance, but for now, just getting everything to build on java 8 & 9 is enough to be getting on with.

Unfortunately, that means that your work is not compatible with the direction I think we'll take. I've made similar changes to Chronicle-Bytes and Chronicle-Wire allowing them to be build with java 9:

`mvn -P java9 test`

If you'd be happy to redo some of the work against the master branch of -Bytes or -Wire, such that it will build on *either* java 8 or java 9, then please submit a pull-request for review.

If so, you'll need to run `mvn install -P java9` in Chronicle-Core, and override the `chronicle-core` artifact version in (e.g.) Chronicle-Bytes.

text:
Not so much a roadmap, more a need to make sure that all the OpenHFT projects build/execute on JDK9.

Since I don't really know what all the problems are going to be yet, it's hard to figure out exactly what will be required.

If you'd like to help, then discovering and raising issues against the OpenHFT projects would be a good start. Feel free to fix any problems you find ;)

In terms of ordering, projects should be validated in the order that they appear in this file:

https://github.com/OpenHFT/OpenHFT/blob/master/chronicle-bom/pom.xml#L43

We'll want to first deal with any breaking API changes (i.e. the char[] -> bytes[] change), so that the code can run on either Java8 or Java9. Any Java9-specific features will end up as a Jigsaw module for Java9 in this repo:

https://github.com/OpenHFT/Chronicle-JDK9

text:
Add a createDirectories with better error messages
If you have a broken link directory;
- File.mkdirs() return false without any error message.
- Files.createDirectories(path) complains the FileAlreadyExistsException which is confusing.

If a directory is read only
- File.mkdirs() return false without any error message.

If a file already exists with that name
- File.mkdirs() return false without any error message.
- Files.createDirectories(path) complains the FileAlreadyExistsException which is less confusing.
clean: add a createdirectories with better error messages if you have a broken link directory file mkdirs return false without any error message files createdirectories path complains the filealreadyexistsexception which is confusing if a directory is read only file mkdirs return false without any error message if a file already exists with that name file mkdirs return false without any error message files createdirectories path complains the filealreadyexistsexception which is less confusing

text:
Check that boolean is either true or false.
To reduce typos, boolean values are checked to be in any case

```
true
t
yes
y
```
or
```
false
f
no
n
```
Empty String is ok if parsing a Boolean.
Anything else may produce a warning or an error.

text:
Dragging from Window to Dock Control
Visual studio has 2 scenarios:

1) User drags the titlebar to a dock control.
- When this happens the mouse cursor is set to normal.
- The chrome remains.
- DockTargets are in popups with TopMost=True set.


2) User drags a tab from a window to dock control.
- Mouse cursor is set to normal.
- The chrome and other parts of the window are hidden.
- TopMost dock targets are shown.

/// <summary>

{

}

App freezes if you try to drag to PC desktop or other App
This is because it wants to binary serialize the data for another app to read in.

We need to either disable the option to drop outside the app (I don't know how or if its possible)

or support some kind of serialization, perhaps we can serialize the type name as utf8 encoded string?

text:
Add support for pinning views
Update: https://github.com/wieslawsoltes/Dock/pull/164 brings new model for pinned dock, the pinned docks are supported only in IToolDock.

- [x] Implement object model
- [ ] Implement dock factory logic
- [ ] Implement UI presentation

Proposal for pinned views support in Dock control.

# Model

* Add `IToolDock` interface to controls to be used for pinned views in tool dock.
* Add `IsExpanded` property to `IToolDock`.
* Add `AutoHide` property to `IToolDock`.
* Add implementation to `INPC`, `ReactiveUI` and `Avalonia` models.
* When `IDockable` is pinned, remove it from visibible dockable collection and add to pinned dockables collection.

# UI

* Add `TabStrip` with `PinnedDockables`  and pinned dockables detail view to  `ToolControl`.
* If the pin button for `IDockable` is clicked by user remove it from visibible dockable collection and add to pinned dockables collection..
* If the user clicks on the `TabStrip` and `AutoHide` is set to `True` it reveals the tool overlaying the central UI and sets `IsExpanded` to `true`, if cursor is not over the view and `AutoHide` is set to `true` set `IsExpanded` to `false`.
* When user clicks the pin button and `AutoHide` is set to `true` set the `AutoHide` to `false` and  `IsExpanded` to `true` so the dock no more auto-hides views.

text:
Thanks, It's good to know that JLBH now provides access to the raw percentiles. I think that obtaining them as presented https://github.com/OpenHFT/Chronicle-Core/blob/942f845184e433f59285a11e030f4004c29e84a6/src/test/java/net/openhft/chronicle/core/jlbh/JLBHTest.java will be still my preferred way as it

* provides better API (reduces Connascence of Meaning by providing the names of the percentiles as opposed to simply array of numbers)
* is thread safe, when you run the benchmark using multiple threads
* is unit tested

Either way, this issue is done, thanks for closing.

text:
Add support for unique micro second timestamps
This is useful for having unique ids which have an embedded timestamp.  This is useful for

- ids which are unique even if a service restarts.
- ids are unique provided that are not created at a sustained rate of 1 million per second.

text:
Allow tolerant/lenient parser of +/- infinity and NaN
Hi,

I know JSON norms does not accept these value, but in our project, we need to have NaN or Infinity, as this is provided by our scientific data. Maybe we shouldn't have used Json, but now we would like to have a Json Parser a bit more lenient, as the Gson parser, that with a configuration, can read and write NaN and +/- infinity. Thank you!

text:
serialize java Hashmap
hello ! 
i use json-io for some years now and want to update from json.io 2.4 to json-io 4 
but there are some problems with the new serialization format of maps: 
the old forlmat was with @keys[,,,,],@items[...] 
this was the perfect format for serializing object to mongo. 
in the mongo you can't query map keys containing '.' . But with the old format there was no problem. 
it would be nice if we can switch between both formats

text:
The way `DockControl` is using layout has changed:
https://github.com/wieslawsoltes/Dock/blob/cc67992ce1bca09b01b78c66e59b74588cb89ebf/samples/AvaloniaDemo/MainWindow.xaml#L56
Now:
```XAML
<idc:DockControl Layout="{Binding Layout}"/>
```
Before:
```XAML
<idc:DockControl DataContext="{Binding Layout}"/>
```
You need bind your layout to `Layout` property instead to `DataContext`.
clean: the way is using layout has changed now before you need bind your layout to property instead to

text:
That's huge diff from AvaloniaUI, not sure what to look for.

Anyway, we already allow user to override `Window` type, see:
https://github.com/wieslawsoltes/Dock/blob/7660b73379b7ce4d9ec35ce4e70d1555191a6268/samples/AvaloniaDemo/Factories/DemoDockFactory.cs#L312-L328

The user `Window` class needs to only implement `IDockHost` interface and `HostLocator` will do the rest:
https://github.com/wieslawsoltes/Dock/blob/7660b73379b7ce4d9ec35ce4e70d1555191a6268/src/Dock.Model/Core/IDockHost.cs#L9

https://github.com/wieslawsoltes/Dock/blob/7660b73379b7ce4d9ec35ce4e70d1555191a6268/src/Dock.Avalonia/Controls/HostWindow.cs#L17

text:
Use styles in DockControl
```XAML
<!-- Copyright (c) Wiesław Šoltés. All rights reserved. -->
<!-- Licensed under the MIT license. See LICENSE file in the project root for full license information. -->
<Styles xmlns="https://github.com/avaloniaui"
        xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml"
        xmlns:id="clr-namespace:Dock.Avalonia;assembly=Dock.Avalonia"
        xmlns:idc="clr-namespace:Dock.Avalonia.Controls;assembly=Dock.Avalonia"
        xmlns:converters="clr-namespace:Dock.Avalonia.Converters;assembly=Dock.Avalonia"
        xmlns:Dock="clr-namespace:Dock.Model;assembly=Dock.Model"
        xmlns:Controls="clr-namespace:Dock.Model.Controls;assembly=Dock.Model">
    <Style Selector="idc|DockControl">
        <Style.Resources>
            <converters:OrientationConverter x:Key="OrientationConverter"/>
            <converters:AlignmentConverter x:Key="AlignmentConverter"/>
        </Style.Resources>
        <Setter Property="Template">
            <ControlTemplate>
                <ContentControl Content="{TemplateBinding Layout}">
                    <ContentControl.DataTemplates>
                        <DataTemplate DataType="Controls:ISplitterDock">
                            <idc:ProportionalStackPanelSplitter>
                                <idc:ProportionalStackPanelSplitter.Styles>
                                    <Style Selector="idc|ProportionalStackPanelSplitter">
                                        <Setter Property="Background" Value="Transparent"/>
                                    </Style>
                                </idc:ProportionalStackPanelSplitter.Styles>
                            </idc:ProportionalStackPanelSplitter>
                        </DataTemplate>
                        <DataTemplate DataType="Controls:IDocumentDock">
                            <idc:DocumentControl>
                                <idc:DocumentControl.Styles>
                                    <Style Selector="idc|DocumentControl">
                                        <Setter Property="idc:ProportionalStackPanelSplitter.Proportion" Value="{Binding Proportion}"/>
                                    </Style>
                                </idc:DocumentControl.Styles>
                            </idc:DocumentControl>
                        </DataTemplate>
                        <DataTemplate DataType="Controls:IToolDock">
                            <idc:DockToolChrome IsActive="{Binding IsActive}">
                                <idc:DockToolChrome.Styles>
                                    <Style Selector="idc|DockToolChrome">
                                        <Setter Property="idc:ProportionalStackPanelSplitter.Proportion" Value="{Binding Proportion}"/>
                                    </Style>
                                </idc:DockToolChrome.Styles>
                                <idc:ToolControl/>
                            </idc:DockToolChrome>
                        </DataTemplate>
                        <DataTemplate DataType="Controls:IProportionalDock">
                            <ItemsControl Items="{Binding VisibleDockables}">
                                <ItemsControl.Styles>
                                    <Style Selector="ItemsControl">
                                        <Setter Property="idc:ProportionalStackPanelSplitter.Proportion" Value="{Binding Proportion}"/>
                                    </Style>
                                </ItemsControl.Styles>
                                <ItemsControl.ItemsPanel>
                                    <ItemsPanelTemplate>
                                        <idc:ProportionalStackPanel Name="DropProportional">
                                            <idc:ProportionalStackPanel.Styles>
                                                <Style Selector="idc|ProportionalStackPanel">
                                                    <Setter Property="id:DockProperties.IsDropArea" Value="True" />
                                                    <Setter Property="Background" Value="Transparent" />
                                                    <Setter Property="Orientation" Value="{Binding Orientation, Converter={StaticResource OrientationConverter}}" />
                                                </Style>
                                            </idc:ProportionalStackPanel.Styles>
                                        </idc:ProportionalStackPanel>
                                    </ItemsPanelTemplate>
                                </ItemsControl.ItemsPanel>
                            </ItemsControl>
                        </DataTemplate>
                        <DataTemplate DataType="Controls:IPinDock">
                            <DockPanel Name="DropPin">
                                <DockPanel.Styles>
                                    <Style Selector="DockPanel">
                                        <Setter Property="id:DockProperties.IsDropArea" Value="True"/>
                                        <Setter Property="Background" Value="Transparent"/>
                                    </Style>
                                </DockPanel.Styles>
                                <TabStrip Items="{Binding VisibleDockables}" SelectedItem="{Binding AvtiveDockable, Mode=TwoWay}">
                                    <TabStrip.Styles>
                                        <Style Selector="TabStrip">
                                            <Setter Property="Focusable" Value="False" />
                                            <Setter Property="ClipToBounds" Value="False" />
                                            <Setter Property="DockPanel.Dock" Value="{Binding Alignment, Converter={StaticResource AlignmentConverter}}" />
                                        </Style>
                                        <Style Selector="TabStrip:empty">
                                            <Setter Property="IsVisible" Value="False" />
                                        </Style>
                                        <Style Selector="TabStrip /template/ ItemsPresenter#PART_ItemsPresenter > WrapPanel">
                                            <Setter Property="Orientation" Value="Vertical"/>
                                        </Style>
                                    </TabStrip.Styles>
                                    <TabStrip.DataTemplates>
                                        <DataTemplate DataType="Dock:IDockable">
                                            <StackPanel Name="DragPin">
                                                <StackPanel.Styles>
                                                    <Style Selector="StackPanel">
                                                        <Setter Property="id:DockProperties.IsDragArea" Value="True"/>
                                                        <Setter Property="id:DockProperties.IsDropArea" Value="True"/>
                                                        <Setter Property="Background" Value="Transparent"/>
                                                        <Setter Property="Orientation" Value="Horizontal"/>
                                                        <Setter Property="Spacing" Value="2"/>
                                                    </Style>
                                                </StackPanel.Styles>
                                                <TextBlock Text="{Binding Title}" Classes="drag" Margin="2" />
                                            </StackPanel>
                                        </DataTemplate>
                                    </TabStrip.DataTemplates>
                                </TabStrip>
                                <ContentControl Content="{Binding AvtiveDockable}" IsVisible="{Binding IsExpanded}"/>
                            </DockPanel>
                        </DataTemplate>
                        <DataTemplate DataType="Controls:IRootDock">
                            <DockPanel Name="DropRoot">
                                <DockPanel.Styles>
                                    <Style Selector="DockPanel">
                                        <Setter Property="id:DockProperties.IsDropArea" Value="True"/>
                                        <Setter Property="Background" Value="Transparent"/>
                                    </Style>
                                </DockPanel.Styles>
                                <ContentControl Content="{Binding Top}" DockPanel.Dock="Top"/>
                                <ContentControl Content="{Binding Bottom}" DockPanel.Dock="Bottom"/>
                                <ContentControl Content="{Binding Left}" DockPanel.Dock="Left"/>
                                <ContentControl Content="{Binding Right}" DockPanel.Dock="Right"/>
                                <Carousel Items="{Binding VisibleDockables}" SelectedItem="{Binding AvtiveDockable, Mode=TwoWay}" IsVirtualized="False"/>
                            </DockPanel>
                        </DataTemplate>
                    </ContentControl.DataTemplates>
                </ContentControl>
            </ControlTemplate>
        </Setter>
    </Style>
</Styles>
```
clean: use styles in dockcontrol

text:
SplitToWindow is not collapsing splitter
Collapsing the splitters does not work if a tool is dropped into a new window.
The resulting splitter that is left can crash the application if you accidently use it.

I tried to fix it myself but I was not sucessfull without messing up the entire code structure.
However the problem currently is that the line:
 `RemoveDockable(dockable, true);` (Factorybase. line 723) 
passes a tooldock that has children.
RemoveDockable calles Collapse() but that does not work if it has children.
`if (dock.IsCollapsable && dock.VisibleDockables.Count == 0)`


![2019-09-1318-49-01 (1)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25281882/64885761-302ff100-d665-11e9-8562-9a055ea6b94f.gif)

text:
StringBuilder/String "coder" field reflection caching
Currently, for each string (field or value) deserialized using the high-level Chronicle-Queue interface. The `String`/`StringBuilder` `coder` value is assessed using reflection ( to be more precise, the wrong field is assessed, an exception is thrown and then recovered from).

This incurs quite a huge performance penalty for deserialization operation, you might imagine.

I've issued [this](https://github.com/OpenHFT/Chronicle-Core/pull/89) PR to fix this behavior.
clean: stringbuilder coder field reflection caching currently for each string field or value deserialized using the high level chronicle queue interface the value is assessed using reflection to be more precise the wrong field is assessed an exception is thrown and then recovered from this incurs quite a huge performance penalty for deserialization operation you might imagine i ve issued this pr to fix this behavior

text:
json-io does uses the @Keys/@Items format when a non-string key is used within a Map, otherwise it serializes to JSON in the format where the keys are String keys in json to the associated values.

If you want, you could add a flag that json-io would look at that would override this behavior.  json-io has many existing options that can be turned on/off already.  A pull request that adds support for this (and a test) would be welcomed.

text:
False available while bulk testing 
Hi while testing the URLs in bulk I am receiving false positives such as fhdianlanzhijia.com.
I changed the default server and request time (1.5 to 3 secs to prevent random responses) but all failed. 
Single test return accurate result while bulk is inaccurate.
I am checking the possible reasons and will ping you in case find the issue.
clean: false available while bulk testing hi while testing the urls in bulk i am receiving false positives such as fhdianlanzhijia com i changed the default server and request time 1 5 to 3 secs to prevent random responses but all failed single test return accurate result while bulk is inaccurate i am checking the possible reasons and will ping you in case find the issue

text:
Hi, is this a git clone or built binary? it seems that is a clone, the latest clone includes a fix to #5 which was supposed to be the same false positive issue..

Please check this commit 60cd6c646c8da2cbc51366d5e0f1ba86c9749287 that refers exactly to that fix, the checker looks for certain conditions to determine if a domain is not available. Earlier this checker mechanism was separate but now is supposed to be common to both single and bulk whois to maintain results consistent.

I don't use the tool often so this is largely unmaintained. if you think you may have sensitive information you would like to share to get the thing solved don't hesitate to contact via email instead, a fix can be posted here later.

Also thanks for using the tool.

text:
It's a shortfall of the app deciding that available will be the default case, that was a ambiguous design decision i took as a way to prefer false availability rather than false unavailability as long as you don't too many false positives... I may be able to check this eventually again but not in the meanwhile. From a base test i think bulk may be broken after all...

Improve ThreadDump by adding waiting method
Some tests using ThreadDump could be substantially sped up if there was a method that waited for all required threads to close. This would prevent tests from having to wait an arbitrary time before checking thread consistency potentially waiting unnecessarily long.

text:
Compatibility issues on JDK 14
Hi

as previously described in [here](https://github.com/OpenHFT/Chronicle-Queue/issues/652)

sun.nio.ch.FileChannelImpl.map0 implementation has changed on JDK 14, requiring an additional boolean param.

This makes CQ unusable on that version of the JDK (works fine on JDK 13).

Tested with CQ version 5.19.2

I've opened a [PR](https://github.com/OpenHFT/Chronicle-Core/pull/98)

text:
Improve EventHandler termination performance
It is possible to create a subclass of InvalidEventHandlerException that only exists as a singleton (e.g. SingletonInvalidEventHandlerException) and that is statically created. EventHandlers that only use the InvalidEventHandlerException as a means of removing itself from the EventLoop could use the static Exception for pure removal with no underlying exception to signal. This will improve loop performance and reduce jittering.

Originally filed here https://github.com/OpenHFT/Chronicle-Threads/issues/32
clean: improve eventhandler termination performance it is possible to create a subclass of invalideventhandlerexception that only exists as a singleton e g singletoninvalideventhandlerexception and that is statically created eventhandlers that only use the invalideventhandlerexception as a means of removing itself from the eventloop could use the static exception for pure removal with no underlying exception to signal this will improve loop performance and reduce jittering originally filed here

text:
WeakReferenceCleaner thread lingering under certain conditions 
When an application is run via `mvn exec:java` and subsequently completes, the exec plugin will check for threads that are alive. (including daemon threads). These threads are then interrupted and waited upon for some 30 seconds. If they are still alive, an error message is shown. It is only after this that shutdown hooks are executed. 

The way the cleaner `chronicle-weak-reference-cleaner` is handled, it will always be reported as alive and thus it will create the problems above. It would be better to run said thread as a plain daemon thread.
clean: weakreferencecleaner thread lingering under certain conditions when an application is run via and subsequently completes the exec plugin will check for threads that are alive including daemon threads these threads are then interrupted and waited upon for some 30 seconds if they are still alive an error message is shown it is only after this that shutdown hooks are executed the way the cleaner is handled it will always be reported as alive and thus it will create the problems above it would be better to run said thread as a plain daemon thread

text: You can also use `-Dexec.cleanupDaemonThreads=false` (or put cleanupDaemonThreads in the exec plugin's config section in pom.xml)
clean: you can also use or put cleanupdaemonthreads in the exec plugin s config section in pom xml

text:
Add a standardized way of reporting elapsed time
In many of our libraries, we report various elapsed times (e.g. when a read took more than a certain amount of time). These reports vary greatly and are sometimes hard to read for a human.

These messages:
```
TcpEventHandler Non blocking read took 1856304 us.
MappedFile took 19291231 us to grow file /tmp/a.bin
FileShrinker run 93600 s ago.
```
Could instead be:
```
TcpEventHandler Non blocking read took 1.86 s (1856304123 ns)
MappedFile took 19.3 s (19291231113 ns) us to grow file /tmp/a.bin
FileShrinker run last 1 day and 2 hours (93600000000000 ns) ago.
```
We should have one human-readable form and another machine-readable form.
clean: add a standardized way of reporting elapsed time in many of our libraries we report various elapsed times e g when a read took more than a certain amount of time these reports vary greatly and are sometimes hard to read for a human these messages could instead be we should have one human readable form and another machine readable form

Added a FlakyTestRunner
To distinguish between test which rarely fails and those which reliably fail.
i.e. this highlights when a rarely failing test reliably fails rather than @Ignoring it.

text:
Standardize how ReferenceCounted resources are managed and traced
Added tracking of `ReferenceOwner`s to ensure
- a resource isn't reserved multiple times by the same thing
- a resource isn't released which didn't reserve it.
- a resource isn't released multiple times.
- when a resource isn't free, all the owners can be logged with stack traces.

Added tracking for threads so that when a thread fails to stop, the location of factory is reported.

Added {Module}TestCommon classes to be the parent of every test without one to standardise the checks made after a test is run.

text:
Enable better ReferenceCounted performance
Some `ReferenceCounted` entities determine their close state by evaluating if `refCount < 1`. This might potentially delegate to slower methods such as `ConcurrentHashMap::size` or `IdentityHashMap::size`.

We could add a method `ReferenceCounted::isReleased` that is backed by an AtomicInteger, in turn, set by `releaseLast()`.

text:
Improved consistency of support for Seconds, Millis, Micros and Nanos.
Using long for a time stamp has been remarked into ranges for seconds, milli, micros, nanos so that a single `long` can hold any of these with the following limitations.

All dates are between `1970-04-17T18:02:52.037` and `2262-04-11T23:47:16.854775807` (except for second which can be from epoch.
This allows timestamps with different scales to be identified and converted up/down as needed without issue.

text:
ReflectionBasedByteBufferCleanerService::clean NPEs
When running example4 `ReplicationNotifications` in Chronicle-Map-Enterprise-Demo, the application fails and subsequently is unable to release resources:

Java 8
```
[background~resource~releaser] WARN net.openhft.chronicle.core.io.BackgroundResourceReleaser - Failed in release/close
java.lang.NullPointerException: Cannot invoke "java.lang.invoke.MethodHandle.invoke(Object)" because "net.openhft.chronicle.core.cleaner.impl.reflect.ReflectionBasedByteBufferCleanerService.CLEAN_METHOD" is null
	at net.openhft.chronicle.core.cleaner.impl.reflect.ReflectionBasedByteBufferCleanerService.clean(ReflectionBasedByteBufferCleanerService.java:64)
	at net.openhft.chronicle.bytes.NativeBytesStore.performRelease(NativeBytesStore.java:541)
	at net.openhft.chronicle.core.io.BackgroundResourceReleaser.performRelease(BackgroundResourceReleaser.java:79)
	at net.openhft.chronicle.core.io.BackgroundResourceReleaser.runReleaseResources(BackgroundResourceReleaser.java:28)
	at java.base/java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:832)
```

Java 15 (with useful NPE messages)
```
java.lang.NullPointerException: Cannot invoke "java.lang.invoke.MethodHandle.invoke(Object)" because "net.openhft.chronicle.core.cleaner.impl.reflect.ReflectionBasedByteBufferCleanerService.CLEAN_METHOD" is null
	at net.openhft.chronicle.core.cleaner.impl.reflect.ReflectionBasedByteBufferCleanerService.clean(ReflectionBasedByteBufferCleanerService.java:64)
	at net.openhft.chronicle.bytes.NativeBytesStore.performRelease(NativeBytesStore.java:541)
	at net.openhft.chronicle.core.io.BackgroundResourceReleaser.performRelease(BackgroundResourceReleaser.java:79)
	at net.openhft.chronicle.core.io.BackgroundResourceReleaser.runReleaseResources(BackgroundResourceReleaser.java:28)
	at java.base/java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:832)
```

If `CLEANER_METHOD` is unavailable (i.e. `null`), then `clean()` should not invoke any methods.
clean: reflectionbasedbytebuffercleanerservice clean npes when running example4 in chronicle map enterprise demo the application fails and subsequently is unable to release resources java 8 java 15 with useful npe messages if is unavailable i e then should not invoke any methods

text:
HostWindows can't leave screen on linux
On Linux HostWindows behave differently than normal Windows. You can't move them outside of screen boundary which makes it hard to place them back to the main window.
![ezgif-3-389ee8d3bf5f](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25281882/94546777-a68e9980-024e-11eb-9903-a90c6c42fed2.gif)

It would be nice to be able to move them partially out of bounds like normal windows:
![Screenshot from 2020-09-29 12-28-51](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25281882/94547354-77c4f300-024f-11eb-862b-ac8d9f3ef619.png)
clean: hostwindows can t leave screen on linux on linux hostwindows behave differently than normal windows you can t move them outside of screen boundary which makes it hard to place them back to the main window ezgif 3 it would be nice to be able to move them partially out of bounds like normal windows screenshot from 2020 09 29 12 28 51

text:
Add a library announcer
Whenever a Chronicle library, like Queue or Map, is first used in an application, it would be useful if certain information elements are output to the logs. This would greatly simplify the reconstruction of the software stack used. For example, upon detecting an anomaly or when analyzing old logs. The following information elements are proposed:

* Library name (e.g. Chronicle-Queue)
* Library version (e.g. 2.20.42)
* Java version
* Process id
* Library specific additional information (e.g. for datagrid: the used YAML configuration file and the server id)

Output to the log should be de-duplicated in order to reduce log clutter.

In view of this, I proposed that we add a common method in Core that outputs said information elements in a standardized way and that filters any attempts to output duplicate data.
clean: add a library announcer whenever a chronicle library like queue or map is first used in an application it would be useful if certain information elements are output to the logs this would greatly simplify the reconstruction of the software stack used for example upon detecting an anomaly or when analyzing old logs the following information elements are proposed library name e g chronicle queue library version e g 2 20 42 java version process id library specific additional information e g for datagrid the used yaml configuration file and the server id output to the log should be de duplicated in order to reduce log clutter in view of this i proposed that we add a common method in core that outputs said information elements in a standardized way and that filters any attempts to output duplicate data

text:
Changed AbstractCloseable to only be isClosed()=true after performClose() has been performed
When close() is called isClosing() == true
if not closed, set to closing, if already closing and performCloseInBackground() == false, wait for closed
Finally set the isClosed() = true as performClose returns.

text:
Is there a way to avoid ClassCastException without using @type fields on a JSON object?
If I attempt to deserialize JSON that was serialized with the default JsonWriter type settings, I can cast it to a typed object successfully. However, if I attempt to deserialize JSON that was serialized with JsonWriter.TYPE = false, I receive a ClassCastException.

Is there any way to avoid this without needing to rely on the `@type` parameters? The reason I'm asking is because the objects I use are quite complex, and there's a lot of `@type` data being sent. Not serializing `@type` parameters can help me save ~3kB per request on smaller objects in my system (~6kB per round-trip).

Perhaps a solution would be new implementation of method `JsonReader.readObject(Class)` that would make a best attempt at deserialization without any `@type` parameters? Using generics, theoretically it could recursively walk the JsonObject structure and attempt to match the value up with the values of declared Fields on the Class object given, and you could avoid infinite recursion by using the already inbuilt `@ref` and `@id` tags. These are just my first thoughts on a solution, maybe you have something more elegant in mind.

Below is the deserialization code, and the full exception stack trace.

```
JsonReader jsonReader = new JsonReader(request.getInputStream(), DBObjectServletUtils.jsonObjectOptions);
object = (T) jsonReader.readObject();
```


```
java.lang.ClassCastException: com.cedarsoftware.util.io.JsonObject cannot be cast to com.safeharbormonitoring.mgmt.backend.AbstractDBObject
	at com.safeharbormonitoring.mgmt.api.DBObjectServlet.doPut(DBObjectServlet.java:216)
	at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:663)
	at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:741)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:231)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:166)
	at org.apache.tomcat.websocket.server.WsFilter.doFilter(WsFilter.java:53)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:193)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:166)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardWrapperValve.invoke(StandardWrapperValve.java:200)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardContextValve.invoke(StandardContextValve.java:96)
	at org.apache.catalina.authenticator.AuthenticatorBase.invoke(AuthenticatorBase.java:490)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardHostValve.invoke(StandardHostValve.java:139)
	at org.apache.catalina.valves.ErrorReportValve.invoke(ErrorReportValve.java:92)
	at org.apache.catalina.valves.AbstractAccessLogValve.invoke(AbstractAccessLogValve.java:668)

text:
If you turn of the @type, then it is best to read the JSON into JsonReader using the API that returns a "Map of Maps" which will prevent any ClassCastExceptions.  Here is an example in Groovy:
```
// shown using Groovy short-hand for Map of options.  See options below.
String json = // some JSON obtained from wherever
Object obj = JsonReader.jsonToJava(json, [(JsonReader.USE_MAPS): true]) 
```
clean: if you turn of the type then it is best to read the json into jsonreader using the api that returns a map of maps which will prevent any classcastexceptions here is an example in groovy

text: Is there a challenge or a reason not to create functionality to serialize into a typed object (not a map of maps) without storing type info in the JSON (if you are given the class information as a parameter of the method)?

text:
Yes, there is a challenge to using JSON to store/retrieve to a set of Java
classes without placing type information in the JSON.  Simple example, I
have a field in JSON that has an object type next to it:

```
 {
   "field1": { "name": "John", "lastname": "DeRegnaucourt"}
   "field2": true
}
```

Now the Java object you want to read it into looks like this (two examples)
Class A
{
   Map field1;
   Boolean field2;
}

Class B
{
   Person field1;
   Boolean field2;
}

Class C
{
  Object field1;
  Boolean field2;
}

In this example, which class should be instantiated to hold the result?  It
is completely ambiguous.  The JSON reader code has a Map when it finishes
reading the  { "name": ...} portion of the JSON.  Now the field it must
assign this too and it's enclosing class, how does it work?  That { "name"
...} portion will work for any of these three classes.  So the reader does
not know which one to instantiate.

This is why I said if you want to work without @types, then use Map of Map
structures and the Map reader version of json-io.  "Hard" Data Transfer
Objects (DTOs) are a thing of the past in my humble opinion.  You can write
rules that generically walk "Map of Map" graphs and validate their values,
transform their values, etc.  Why bother building explicit Java classes
that look the same as Maps, with hard-coded fields and getter/setters on
them?

This spills into a more advanced technique where you can create "DTO"
classes that are derived (extend) LinkedHashMap.  Think about these data
transfer type classes - why do you need to declare fields on them?  Just
declare API on them - getters/setters and have those methods uses the Map's
put/get to store the values.  These serialize out correctly for Jackson or
json-io.  If you are interested in this technique, I will publish one of
those DTO classes that derives from LinkedHashMap here as an example.


On Tue, Oct 27, 2020 at 8:51 AM bmbanker <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Is there a challenge or a reason not to create functionality to serialized
> into a typed object without storing type info in the JSON (if you are given
> the class information as a parameter of the method)?
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/jdereg/json-io/issues/150#issuecomment-717221462>, or
> unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABI76TXOHVTQ7ABHZI7MU63SM266NANCNFSM4S7M6HHQ>
> .
>

text:
hInt-tuition
Use lossless NN for each N-degree polynomial solver for making fast roots hints in parallel to existing generic solving and caching algorithms. 
Use coefficients as input params and sorted roots as output. 
Additionally max/min root intuition LNN models may be the best choice to simplify the polynomial by devising by the root monomial when the root found is tested and it is correct. 
Any root model also could be considered but it harder to train.

text:
If you compile in intellij then it automatically does this instrumentation btw.

My dream is that the compiler can do all this for us i.e. confirm at compile time. There are a few tools I have looked at:

* the combination of NullAway+ErrorProne seems to be reasonably lightweight
* the checkers framework has good support this but adds a bit of time to your compile

Unfortunately both of these work the opposite way to IntelliJ: IntelliJ assumes that everything is nullable unless you explicitly annotate with @NotNull whereas both of these tools assume the opposite. I believe that you can configure the checkers framework to work the same way as Intellij but I have not spent the time.

If we were to follow the compile time static analysis approach on all our products then we could that all our null-related contracts are being respected, although our customers would not get the same assurances for their code.

text:
Fix potentially nasty rounding error in unsafe operations
Arithmetic operations involving two ints are performed with `int` precision and when a `long` result is expected, widening takes place *after* computation. Thus, the result of adding two positive int values might be negative and subsequent use of the result with Unsafe operations might be disastrous. 

At least one of the `int` operands should be cast to `long` before these types of operations.
clean: fix potentially nasty rounding error in unsafe operations arithmetic operations involving two ints are performed with precision and when a result is expected widening takes place after computation thus the result of adding two positive int values might be negative and subsequent use of the result with unsafe operations might be disastrous at least one of the operands should be cast to before these types of operations

text:
I understand your concerns @JerryShea 

However, I think that it is better to immediately throw an exception if the invariants of the method do not hold rather than detecting the problem at a later stage, in some unlikely cases even in another thread. The JIT compiler is able to inline the assertions if stacked. This is equivalent to using the ubiquitous `Objects::requireNonNull` which is widely seen as uncontroversial. 

The compiler still needs to do null checking under the hood so it is likely that the performance impact is negligible.

That said, I think we should do some benchmarking once we have a working candidate up and running to confirm this before we merge this potential feature with the master branch.

text:
Thread's interrupt flag was somehow cleared throwing an AssertionError 
error reported when shutting down a component that tails a number of queues:

```
java.lang.AssertionError
at net.openhft.chronicle.core.Jvm$CommonInterruptible.interrupt(Jvm.java:1044)
at net.openhft.chronicle.core.Jvm.lambda$doNotCloseOnInterrupt9$4(Jvm.java:935)
at jdk.proxy1/com.sun.proxy.jdk.proxy1.$Proxy29.interrupt(Unknown Source)
at java.base/java.lang.Thread.interrupt(Thread.java:996)
at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.interruptIfStarted(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:665)
at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.interruptWorkers(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:763)
at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.shutdownNow(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1409)
at java.base/java.util.concurrent.Executors$DelegatedExecutorService.shutdownNow(Executors.java:693)
```

Looking at the code in CommonInterruptible, it seems as though the Thread's interrupt flag was somehow cleared before the assert check was made:

```
assert Thread.currentThread().isInterrupted();
```

Since this has been observed, please log a warning rather than throwing an AssertionError when the thread's interrupted flag has been cleared.

The environment was JDK15, running inside docker on ubuntu, BOM version 2.20.193.

add support methods for asserting common invariants background many methods and constructors have some invariants i e restrictions on the values being passed to them for example an index is often non negative whereas a power of two parameter is often limited to a value between 0 and 63 we should almost always check these invariants e g as early as possible in public methods and assert the invariants e g in private methods this is of particular importance in cases where the parameter is used later for example in a constructor when passed on as a parameter to a thread or in a delegator current support java and core provides some useful methods for asserting invariants of which the method is perhaps the most well known we can also annotate methods with to state the api contract there is an optimized in core s own that is using the intrinsic method i think later versions of java will do the equivalent with the regular method proposed additions support methods and annotations could be added in core as per below assertions we could add methods such as throws an if val 1 throws an if val 0 throws an if val 0 or val 63 throws a if val 1 annotations we could add annotations such as example performance impact the jit compiler will be able to remove redundant checking e g null checks via in lining in code paths asserting invariants early can in some cases be faster than asserting or implicitly asserting them by use later there are cases where the performance will be affected negatively conclusion i think using these methods in our libraries would improve quality and api clarity

text:
A `Builder` should be more thoroughly specified. For example, there is a conceptual difference between a `Builder` and a `Factory` in the way that a Builder's `build()` method can typically only be invoked at most once whereas a `Factory` can be invoked any number of times.

A `Supplier` is generally considered a `Factory` so, in my opinion, a `Builder` should not extend `Supplier`. If a `Supplier` is needed one could instead provide `builder::build`.

Hence, a `Builder` must either prevent its build method from being invoked more than one time or it must make defensive copies of its internal state (if using transitive mutable states such as maps, lists etc) each time it produces an instance.

Calling getClass() (as null-check) on Zing's sun.misc.VM caused a crash because we were calling it on something returned from `sun.misc.Unsafe#staticFieldBase`. The javadoc for this method states that the return value from this method is "not guaranteed to be a real Object, and it should not be used in any way except as argument to the get and put routines in this class."

The code has been modified to use reflection instead of Unsafe.

V  [libjvm.so+0x5ec4b7]  InterpreterRuntime::resolve_invoke(JavaThread*, Bytecodes::Code)+0x347
j  net.openhft.chronicle.core.util.ObjectUtils.requireNonNull(Ljava/lang/Object;)Ljava/lang/Object;+1
j  net.openhft.chronicle.core.UnsafeMemory.readLong(Ljava/lang/Object;J)J+1

text:
We should make it explicit how many instances of utility classes we should expect to see which is 0 rather than making it indirectly with a private constructor which can be called from a nested class or reflection for example. There are many examples in our code and others where you get a constructor and call setAccessible(true) and this allows utility instances to be created via deserialization i.e. input. This doesn't apply to `enum`s.

NOTE: we do create new instances of "dynamic" `enum` but this doesn't use reflection and has checks on it. i.e. the class must extend `DynamicEnum` only Unsfae.allocateInstance can create new instances of a enum so is less likely to used/misused.
clean: we should make it explicit how many instances of utility classes we should expect to see which is 0 rather than making it indirectly with a private constructor which can be called from a nested class or reflection for example there are many examples in our code and others where you get a constructor and call setaccessible true and this allows utility instances to be created via deserialization i e input this doesn t apply to s note we do create new instances of dynamic but this doesn t use reflection and has checks on it i e the class must extend only unsfae allocateinstance can create new instances of a enum so is less likely to used

as described in one of my older blog posts it is actually possible to create spurious enum constants as well so i think the capability to create unwanted instances is there for both alternatives enum or utility class however i think this is of less importance if a user wants to create an instance of a class that is not supposed to be created then let them go ahead my argument for using utility classes i e non instantiable final classes with a private constructor over enums is purely based on api management adding a public enum class will have the following adverse effects on the api a it adds to the class a1 it adds to the class a2 it adds a to the class b it adds a static method c it adds a static method d it adds a static method other issues some users are confused when there is an enum with zero elements code completion in the ide will be polluted with the non related enum methods b c and d it adds some extra enum properties to the class definition so if we have n classes of enum utility classes then we will add an additional of n 3 methods to maintain when ensuring version compatibility also there will be n different static methods doing the same thing e g etc a more stringent way of enforcing a no instance property would be to create utility classes like this this has the advantage of not providing any unrelated api methods and almost guarantees that no instances are created well there is always instrumentation isn t it i think utility classes in internal packages not exposed in the public api may or may not be enums

text:
Param descrete optimization
Test/Sample:

1. Input variables
2. Input each variable possible values (alphabet)
3. Input known math relations between variables
4. Select param variable to optimize
5. Express the variable to optimize
6. Eval the best value for selected param to optimize into the expressed equation
7. Obtain feasible rest subsets of params in the rest of the expressed equation

Now has the constraints for all params to optimize selected one.

text:
Move AbstractCloseable#throwExceptionIfClosed to an expert use interface
throwExceptionIfClosed is a public method, as such, it should probably be moved into its own class, or not made public, as being public is leaking its visibility into the subclasses API. The current method is also mixing concerns because it's also doing both thread checks as well as checking if closed. When the thread check is not required currently the way to turn this off is to override the functionality ( which is a little ugly )

text:
I would suggest something along these lines:

https://github.com/OpenHFT/Chronicle-Core/tree/feature/closeable/src/main/java/net/openhft/chronicle/core/resource

The `FooResource` is using a `ManagedResourceSupport` class to handle resource management. This means it is using something rather than being something. This provides better API control and also opens up for specialized support implementations that can be optimized (e.g. if no thread confinement is needed, a more optimized class can be supplied by the builder). 

There are many aspects to this and I am just showing a rough outline here.

I think these ideas could be realized in a new future core major version bump. In the short term, I would consider splitting up close and thread assertions into separate methods. I would name the thread checking method `assertThreadConfined()`.

text:
Add a zero cost assertion mechanism
Normal assertions using the `assert` keyword have several drawbacks:

* It requires byte code space, thereby increasing code space
* Interpretation mode is slower because more code has to be interpreted
* Compile mode might be substantially slower because the inlining threshold will be consumed by assertion code
* It always produces the same kind of Error (i.e. AssertionError)
* Unless accompanied with an assert message, it provides little extra information as to which invariant did not hold (e.g. "" vs. "The provided index was non-negative (=-3))

It is possible to write an equivalent assertion mechanism that solves all the above (i.e. with no impact on byte code size, interpreting, and compiled code performance). The drawback is that switching on assertions will be non-standard.

Having an assertion mechanism in place is key to discovering bugs in our libraries.
