text:
Improve config handling of more complex types
Currently the config utility for simple string and number values. However more complex values like bigint, or JSON objects get mangled by the `config.ts` script because it receives them on the command line as strings and then stores them into LocalStorage assuming they are the correct type and therefore stringifying the string value and preventing it from being deserialized correctly.

It would actually be simpler for the `config.ts` script to directly set the LocalStorage key as a string, then the `Config` instance would correctly deserialize the object.

Even better would be if we exposed a separate API in the `Config` base class to allow setting just the config keys named in the config spec.
clean: improve config handling of more complex types currently the config utility for simple string and number values however more complex values like bigint or json objects get mangled by the script because it receives them on the command line as strings and then stores them into localstorage assuming they are the correct type and therefore stringifying the string value and preventing it from being deserialized correctly it would actually be simpler for the script to directly set the localstorage key as a string then the instance would correctly deserialize the object even better would be if we exposed a separate api in the base class to allow setting just the config keys named in the config spec

text:
Improve support for autocompleting config values
Some configuration keys like `GO_goOpponent` have a very constrained set of valid keys and it is incumbent on the user to both know what those valid values are and then type them correctly. It would be much nicer if we added a way to define what valid values are in the config spec and then the `config.ts` script could read those values and provide them as possible autocompletions.
clean: improve support for autocompleting config values some configuration keys like have a very constrained set of valid keys and it is incumbent on the user to both know what those valid values are and then type them correctly it would be much nicer if we added a way to define what valid values are in the config spec and then the script could read those values and provide them as possible autocompletions

text:
Support nested Config values
Similar to git config we could support a kind of 'table.key' syntax. This would reduce the total number of config items at the cost of making them harder to edit by hand.


Pros:

- provides namespacing for config values
- more obvious which configs work together
- lets us reduce duplication in naming for similar configs

Cons:

- Current config would need to be reworked to support it
- Substantial design change needed

Meh:

- harder to edit local storage manually

Design questions:

- Storage: JSON objects or new key naming scheme?
- API Design: nested field access or dotted config names?
clean: support nested config values similar to git config we could support a kind of table key syntax this would reduce the total number of config items at the cost of making them harder to edit by hand pros provides namespacing for config values more obvious which configs work together lets us reduce duplication in naming for similar configs cons current config would need to be reworked to support it substantial design change needed meh harder to edit local storage manually design questions storage json objects or new key naming scheme api design nested field access or dotted config names

Reduce desiriability of Bladeburner Operations that reduce population by percentage
Reducing the population too low has a dramatic negative effect on success chance once below a certain threshold.

We should take current population into account when choosing an action and heavily penalize the operations that reduce population by percentage so we don't overuse these operations.

text:
Return terminal command output
It feels a bit pointless to return the commands that the user passed in. It would be nicer to return the actual string outputs that the commands returned.

This presents an issue however in that it is _quite_ difficult to robustly and performantly track the terminal output with all the complexity of how React can batch renders and subtly rewrite the internals of elements.

text:
Terminal Utility should cancel subsequent chained commands when one fails
Currently, when we pass a series of chained commands to `sendTerminalCommand` if one of the commands fails we reject immediately.

This however does not cause subsequent commands to be cancelled. If we're chaining a bunch of commands it's likely that subsequent commands depend to some degree on the earlier commands running correctly. So it would probably be appropriate to at least have the option to cancel subsequent commands when one fails.

text:
NS function dispatcher service
Corporation functions are crazy expensive RAM wise. My current setup scripts take the approach of script-chaining where each script runs one function and then spawns the next in the chain. This is very boilerplate heavy, especially since my standards for scripts have risen higher with autocomplete, flag parsing, usage messages etc. It's also quite brittle and just a pain in the ass to write scripts in that style.

It would be neat to set up a service that listens on a port and allows clients to dispatch expensive one-off NS commands they want to run.

Preliminary thoughts on how to make it RAM efficient without any RAM dodging hacks:

- Current static RAM checker ignores strings so we can safely specify the exact `NS` function to run as a string.
- We should be able to create a type that extracts all the keys from the NS interface as valid arguments!
- Could use a self-spawning architecture to reset dynamic RAM cost (invoke one command, then spawn self to reset RAM cost)
- Or, could dynamically create single use scripts from string concatenation that invoke that particular script. This method could even be an addition to the existing `launch` service

The first design would be slower and probably would want to have an interesting split-daemon structure where we run two invocations of it, one that does the spawning and one that receives and responds to messages. Could probably use a similar `Promise` chain that my terminal lock uses to communicate via a module level variable.

A nice-to-have feature of the client API would be if the type of the function could somehow provide autocomplete for the actual function arguments, that sounds like possibly a pipe-dream however.

text:
Release chunks logic causes RAM overcommit
The harvest script uses a feature of the memory manager that no other script in the game does, the ability to relinquish chunks of memory back to the allocator.

Currently, the way that harvest does this is extremely naive and optimistic. As soon as it calculates that it needs fewer chunks, it sends a `ReleaseChunk` message to the allocator and then the allocator decides which chunks to remove from the allocation owned by that harvest script. The allocator then sends a message back to the harvest script that containing it's full `AllocationResult`.

This API is fundamentally flawed. Because the allocator is in control of which chunks are freed, the only way for the client to correctly utilize this API would be to ensure no scripts are running in any of it's memory chunks, then call the API, then restart the batch hacking process.

This is not a viable solution for how we want the Batch hacking system to function, continuously spawning batches to have continuously ending batches hacking a target.

For this to actually work, there needs to be another round-trip communication before the memory is actually freed. After the server designates which chunks to free (should only send that message instead of the entire allocation result), the client then actually ensures those chunks are no longer being used, _then_ it sends a message saying those chunks are actually free.

This is a lot more work and in the short term we should just remove the release chunks capability.
clean: release chunks logic causes ram overcommit the harvest script uses a feature of the memory manager that no other script in the game does the ability to relinquish chunks of memory back to the allocator currently the way that harvest does this is extremely naive and optimistic as soon as it calculates that it needs fewer chunks it sends a message to the allocator and then the allocator decides which chunks to remove from the allocation owned by that harvest script the allocator then sends a message back to the harvest script that containing it s full this api is fundamentally flawed because the allocator is in control of which chunks are freed the only way for the client to correctly utilize this api would be to ensure no scripts are running in any of it s memory chunks then call the api then restart the batch hacking process this is not a viable solution for how we want the batch hacking system to function continuously spawning batches to have continuously ending batches hacking a target for this to actually work there needs to be another round trip communication before the memory is actually freed after the server designates which chunks to free should only send that message instead of the entire allocation result the client then actually ensures those chunks are no longer being used then it sends a message saying those chunks are actually free this is a lot more work and in the short term we should just remove the release chunks capability

text:
Buy available pre-requisite augmentations from factions when grafting
It's possible to enable grafting an augmentation with pre-reqs by simplying purchasing the pre-req from a faction for later installation. We should make the logic from `automation/buy-augments.ts` available more simply to enable this.
clean: buy available pre requisite augmentations from factions when grafting it s possible to enable grafting an augmentation with pre reqs by simplying purchasing the pre req from a faction for later installation we should make the logic from available more simply to enable this

text:
I think what's happening is actually that we changed the script to measure the _total income_ for return time rather than requiring hacknet nodes to pay for themselves in the return time.

We made this change because buying more hacknet servers has more benefit than just the income they can provide and if we can easily pay for the server we probably want it.

This makes the script slightly less suitable for use with hacknet nodes, but those are a money sink regardless so it doesn't really matter.
clean: i think what s happening is actually that we changed the script to measure the total income for return time rather than requiring hacknet nodes to pay for themselves in the return time we made this change because buying more hacknet servers has more benefit than just the income they can provide and if we can easily pay for the server we probably want it this makes the script slightly less suitable for use with hacknet nodes but those are a money sink regardless so it doesn t really matter

make all communication protocols more type safe currently we imply a relationship between the and but we can do better than that with the typescript type system currently we define port protocol messages like this in this formulation the only thing tying the and is that they have the same name and the in the type isn t obviously related to the type in any way typescript let s us define type aliases with arbitrary types and explicit values are valid types so we can define this messaging protocol more strictly using a discriminated union this describes the actual message much more clearly and provides better type checking for implementing the client it would be nice if we could include the response type as well but i m not sure how to do that the downside to this structure is that we can t define the type using a type alias and we would need to change the class to interact with the new type

That  was correct because JsonObject extended LinkedHashmap but now the docs should say either JsonObject or a Map<> Object to be general.

text:
Sort Memory Allocator Hosts More Sanely
The memory allocator displays worker's in the order they are registered.

Often it's more interesting to look at specific classes of servers, usually the home and purchased servers.

So we should improve the display to group those servers separately.

The user was logged using facbook method and email should NOT be reuired, but the logc stills logoff user .

it shoudl check gacbookid instead. if it exist this means all is good.

Another issue is that after log off it tries to SoccerApp.setUserOnline: ❌ setUserOnline failed, which ofclourse failes because no user is logged. so it should make a check before calling SoccerApp.setUserOnline: ❌ setUserOnline failed if user is logged.

Then another method failes SoccerApp.forceUserOffline: ❌ could not mark offline again because user is not log in, so it should check first is user is logged in before invoking this method.

text:
fix facbook image
when i pulled my public profile from facebook this is the data that was given facebookId "24783685521224061" (string) facebookName "Piotr Górczyński" (string) facebookPhotoUrl "https://graph.facebook.com/24783685521224061/picture" (string) 

when i check the url "https://graph.facebook.com/24783685521224061/picture" the picture attached is showing siluethe non-name blank person picture.

chatgpt suggests that

That silhouette means you’re asking Facebook for the photo without any access token (an anonymous request). If the user’s profile photo isn’t Public, the public endpoint falls back to the blank image.

Option B (guaranteed): fetch with the user’s access token

Right after Facebook login you have an access token. Use it once to resolve the real CDN URL, then cache it.

HTTP (no redirect):

GET https://graph.facebook.com/v20.0/{facebookId}/picture
    ?type=large
    &redirect=0
    &access_token={USER_ACCESS_TOKEN}


Response:

{ "data": { "is_silhouette": false, "url": "https://scontent.xx.fbcdn.net/..." } }


Use data.url as the photo URL in your app (and store it in Firestore). You can also call me/picture instead of {facebookId}/picture.

text:
Rebuild graft list after every install
The queue-graft script works well once we have enough money to install almost anything.

However, during bootstrapping a new Bitnode, it's likely we will have to initially settle for at least one or two lower-cost and lower-improvement augments before we can purchase the really high value augments.

But installing an augment takes long enough that we might earn enough money while installing it to buy a better one than we could have before we started (almost certainly in fact).

So before installing a new augmentation we should rebuild the list from the beginning, and choose the highest value one we can afford right now, rather than relying on a list built at the start of the script.

Also, we should devalue good augments that have a lot of pre-requisites before we have the violet congruity implant, because more pre-reqs means less improvement overall because the entropy virus will grow.

Finally, we should always prioritize installing the violet contgruity implant if we don't have it, no matter what type of augments we are interested in.

text:
Anonymous login
At the moment in the mobile/app/src/main/java/piotr_gorczynski/soccer2/UniversalLoginActivity.java we have 4 methods:
email
google
facebook

I have heard that firebase allows anonymous login. 

so providing that such method exists so i want to add 4th method - anonymous.

0. modify or add another step in gcp\cloud-build\deploy_firebase_with_auth.yaml to enable anonymous login
1. before creating anonmpus user it should provide a warning that "The  anonymous user allows access to certain functions, but in case of (and here list the relevant cases like phone reinstalation, new phone, lost phone, or logoff which lead to loosing link to anonymous account on firebase) the link to anonymous user is lost and it is not possible to login to the same anonymopius account. do you want to proceed?"

Thgis message should be stored in strings and translated to all supported languages.
2. This shoudl creat new entry in authentication and methos anonoymous or relevant one and corresponding user in users collection with login method "anonymous"
3. It should follow the same flow as other logins - ask user for Terms, COnsent, nickname
4. The function firebase\functions\delete-unverified-users should skip deletion of anonymous users

text:
DO not change lanugage to english after logout
AT the moment when user logs out, the interface rerurns to english language even if it was polish or german or spanish or wahtever. 

SO the reuest is that if the user logs out do not clean his lanugage preferences, the ui can stay with the same lanuage, it was.

SImilar to ads consent. If ads consent was given, it is linked to phone, so do not clean the data related to ads consent, it can stay as it was.

text:
Link anonymous account with credentials
There is a method that user can login using anonymous method.

I have heard that there is functionality in firebase to 'convert' anonymous acount to reular account identfied by e.g. email, google or facebook.

Thefore i want you to add on mobile/app/src/main/java/piotr_gorczynski/soccer2/AccountActivity.java a buttion which will say something like "Link to registered account" (of course we need to transle it in strings to all supported languages) and will use linkWithCredential(...) function from firebase.

It shoudl show something like mobile/app/src/main/java/piotr_gorczynski/soccer2/UniversalLoginActivity.java, but without ANonymous option wnd when this login woul d succed, the existing account should be converted to the one with email google or facebook credentails. 

Of course the former document in users/uid should be updated accordingly as with  email or google or facbook data as in normal flow.


My only concern is what will happen if user will already poses registered account with lets say uid=1 and then he will register anonaymous account with uid=2, and then he will try to link anonymous account uid=2 with registered account with uid=1. That would reuire smart merging of all the data. DO you have an idea how we could handle such scenario?

text:
Create a custom mini-shell script
We could implement a more full-featured custom shell on top of our
`launch` service.  This would give us access to a terminal-like
interface no matter what screen we have open, and allow us to manage
scripts more flexibly.

---

## Motivation

As I use my terminal automation utility more, I’ve found it useful to
keep terminal automation scripts running most of the time,
particularly for intelligence grinding.  Right now I often end up
killing that script just to run one or two scripts for testing and
then restarting it again. This is precisely what the `launch` script
is designed to solve—but its ergonomics are a bit awkward.

A custom shell embedded in a script’s log/tail window could provide:
- Seamless launching of scripts through the memory allocator and `launch` service
- A less opinionated approach to argument parsing
- A smoother workflow for quick ad-hoc automation and testing
- The ability to build automation pipelines using shell-like syntax

---

## Features

- Custom shell prompt interface in a script tail window
- Argument parsing under our control (no forced quirks from Bitburner’s terminal)
- Input/output piping with Netscript Ports
- Waiting for processes to exit (`fg`/`bg` commands, `&` suffix)
- Command chaining with `&&` and `||`
- Built-in implementations of basic shell utilities (inspired by Phil Nelson’s minishell assignments), and as a bonus they would work across *all* hosts
- Shell scripting (`if`, `while`) for lightweight automation (stretch goal)

---

## Autocomplete

Autocomplete is one of the trickiest parts without the upcoming `dynamicImport` API in Bitburner 3.0.

Possible interim approach:
- Dynamically generate a helper script that statically imports the script the user is launching
- Run it with `ramOverride` since we only need the autocomplete function
- Communicate with that helper via ports/channels to get completion results

This will become *much* simpler with `dynamicImport` in 3.0.

---

## Advantages

- Cleaner and less awkward usage compared to invoking `launch` directly
- Argument parsing can be made more flexible and intuitive
- Ability to quickly chain together commands for trivial ad-hoc automation
- Consistent environment regardless of which host we’re on

---

## Disadvantages

- A lot of work to implement
- Bitburner terminal commands might need to be reimplemented in
  Javascript to be able to use
- Autocomplete will require some hacky workarounds until 3.0

text:
New Features
i have old version 3.0 of soccer which just allowed to play alone.

on 6th of AUgust the version 7.0 of soccer introduced mulitplayer.
on 16th of ausgust the version 8.0 introduced mulitlingual (9 languages includening pakistan, nepali, urdu, hindu, etc)



but althogh the 1st muliplaye version was launch alomost 3 weeks ago (on 6th of august) and the stast look like this as attached, NO SINGLE  user registered.

I have one tournament open and there is NOBODY to play in the tournament.

i am ready to launch version 9.0 which introduces login via facebook and login via anonymous if sombody doesnt want to reveal his credentilas.

what would you suggest to introduce in this version in order to probe/check the users of version 8.0 and 7.0 - almost 1500 users - whay they do not want to register and participate in tournament?


ChatGPT said:
Thought for 1m 30s

You don’t need more features to “guess.” Ship v9.0 with measurement + tiny in-app research so you learn why people aren’t signing up and fix the friction fast.

What to add in v9.0 (focused + low effort)

Instrument the auth & tournament funnels (GA4)

Log the recommended GA4 events for auth:

login (when they open the sign-in sheet)

sign_up with method = google|email|facebook|anonymous (on success)

sign_up_error (custom) with params code, message, step (on failure/cancel).
GA4 recommended events & how to log events on Android: 
[Google for Developers](https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/collection/ga4/reference/events?utm_source=chatgpt.com)
[Firebase](https://firebase.google.com/docs/analytics/events?utm_source=chatgpt.com)

Add custom steps for your core flow:

tournament_view → tournament_join_start → tournament_join_success|tournament_join_error

In GA4 build a Funnel exploration for these steps to see exactly where users drop. 
[Google Help](https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/9327974?hl=en&utm_source=chatgpt.com)

One-tap “Why not register?” intercept (2 buttons)

When a user dismisses the sign-up sheet or tries to join a tournament while not signed in, show a small bottom sheet:

Title: “Play without account?”

Buttons (each logs signup_decline_reason): just_playing_offline, privacy_concerns, too_complicated, don’t_use_google/email, other.

Keep it one tap (no text input). The event gives you immediate, language-segmented reasons (GA4 already tracks device language). Audiences & user properties let you segment later. 
Firebase
+1

Anonymous play as default → offer linking later

Let users start online as guest (Firebase Anonymous Auth). When they win a match, try to join a tournament, or choose a nickname, prompt: “Save your progress & nickname” and link the anonymous account to Google/Facebook/email. This preserves their stats & nickname. 
[Firebase](https://firebase.google.com/docs/auth/android/anonymous-auth?utm_source=chatgpt.com)

In-App Message (no push permissions needed) to v7/v8 users

Target an audience: App version is 7 or 8 AND not signed up after 2+ sessions. Show a small card explaining benefits + “Register” CTA, and A/B test the copy. In-App Messaging + targeting via Analytics audiences. 
Firebase
+1

A/B test the registration moment & copy (Remote Config)

Remote-config a param like signup_prompt_variant with variants:

on_open, after_first_online_click, after_1_match, only_when_joining_tournament

Also test copy: “Save nickname & ranking” vs “Play tournaments & global ladder.” Use Firebase A/B Testing on Remote Config. 
Firebase
+1

Verify there isn’t a hidden crash or error

Add Crashlytics breadcrumbs around auth and tournament screens and record the auth exceptions you already saw earlier. This will surface silent failures blocking sign-up. 
Firebase
+1

Minimal code you can drop in (Java)

Log a successful sign-up (GA4 recommended event):

FirebaseAnalytics fa = FirebaseAnalytics.getInstance(context);
Bundle p = new Bundle();
p.putString(FirebaseAnalytics.Param.METHOD, "facebook"); // google|email|anonymous
fa.logEvent(FirebaseAnalytics.Event.SIGN_UP, p);


Log a decline reason:

Bundle r = new Bundle();
r.putString("reason", "privacy_concerns"); // just_playing_offline|too_complicated|dont_use_google_email|other
fa.logEvent("signup_decline_reason", r);


Log a tournament funnel step:

Bundle t = new Bundle();
t.putString("tournament_id", tournamentId);
fa.logEvent("tournament_join_start", t);


(Then use GA4 Funnel exploration to analyze drop-offs.) 
[Google Help](https://support.google.com/analytics/answer/9327974?hl=en&utm_source=chatgpt.com)
[Firebase](https://firebase.google.com/docs/analytics/events?utm_source=chatgpt.com)

text:
Normalize contract script solver wire protocol
Currently, some contract answers are turned into JSON strings when sending back to the main port and some are not. We should normalize this so there's less confusion about the actual protocol.

Probably, when we make the contract scripts into a daemon service (#228) part of the message protocol definition should be the response from the contract solver script.

text: Unexpected NumberFormatException logs for environment variable keys ### Specifications When Jawk loads the special ENVIRON array with system environment variables on Windows, it tries to parse every key as a number inside AssocArray.put()/remove(). For non-numeric keys such as USERNAME, PROCESSOR_LEVEL, or SESSIONNAME, this produces unnecessary NumberFormatException messages logged as “Key parse failure” (see attached screenshot). This behavior is misleading, pollutes the logs, and is not compliant with AWK semantics, since associative array keys can be strings.

text:
Add a service monitor
The only reason that I keep a tail window open for things like kataPlay, task selector, queue-args etc. is so I know that they are running.

One of the downsides of the new automation scripts that respect the regular player focus setting when changing tasks is that there is no indicator that a script is running and to kill it you need to either force an error or find the script and kill it.

Instead of this ridiculous situation, it would probably be good to have a single service daemon that essentially does a filtered `ps` and shows the locations of important running scripts other than batch hacking scripts like till/sow/harvest and h/g/w.

We could display important things like:

- script name (with link to open tail)
- host
- ram usage
- runtime

A nice-to-have enhancement would be to categorize scripts by any resources they, the most important of which is probably player focus.
clean: add a service monitor the only reason that i keep a tail window open for things like kataplay task selector queue args etc is so i know that they are running one of the downsides of the new automation scripts that respect the regular player focus setting when changing tasks is that there is no indicator that a script is running and to kill it you need to either force an error or find the script and kill it instead of this ridiculous situation it would probably be good to have a single service daemon that essentially does a filtered and shows the locations of important running scripts other than batch hacking scripts like till and h we could display important things like script name with link to open tail host ram usage runtime a nice to have enhancement would be to categorize scripts by any resources they the most important of which is probably player focus

text:
Create a lock for active player tasks
Player action is a limited resource similar to running commands in the terminal.

We should create a promise based mutex to keep multiple scripts that want to set the player to an action from fighting or chaotically overriding each other.

There are some open questions on how to do this while keeping RAM costs under control. If we want to provide direct usage APIs then each wrapped API will need it's own file. Once we get the remote NS API service working that would provide a cleaner solution. Since these APIs are typically called at a very low frequency they are a really good candidate for it as well.
clean: create a lock for active player tasks player action is a limited resource similar to running commands in the terminal we should create a promise based mutex to keep multiple scripts that want to set the player to an action from fighting or chaotically overriding each other there are some open questions on how to do this while keeping ram costs under control if we want to provide direct usage apis then each wrapped api will need it s own file once we get the remote ns api service working that would provide a cleaner solution since these apis are typically called at a very low frequency they are a really good candidate for it as well

text:
Add UI to Port Service
We can show the next dynamic port to allocate, and for all allocated ports we can display whether they are full or empty.
clean: add ui to port service we can show the next dynamic port to allocate and for all allocated ports we can display whether they are full or empty

text:
Enabling Firebase Analytics
I want you to creat yaml script to enable firebase analytics.

the yaml shoudl be build in similar way as yamls in gcp\cloud-build for example gcp\cloud-build\deploy_realtime_db_locked.yaml.

The yaml shoudl first check if it isnot enabled and only then ebale it.

The analytics should support collecting the analytcis from mobile app e.g. in mobile/app/src/main/java/piotr_gorczynski/soccer2/AnonymousLinkPromptHelper.java there are calls to analyticsManager

text:
Improvements to new Protocol Layer
I'm happy with the client side utilities I've defined already, but the server side support seems to be quite lacking again. In particular, I would like to change the handlers so that they don't need to worry about sending responses at all. If the message includes a response ID then we should expect non-null return value from the handler function. client protocols should be built in such a way that they return objects with errors rather than just a `null` value to indicate failure.

TODO items:

- Move client and `send*` messages outside of `defineProtocol`
- Implement more robust server utilities to make implementing protocol servers easier
clean: improvements to new protocol layer i m happy with the client side utilities i ve defined already but the server side support seems to be quite lacking again in particular i would like to change the handlers so that they don t need to worry about sending responses at all if the message includes a response id then we should expect non null return value from the handler function client protocols should be built in such a way that they return objects with errors rather than just a value to indicate failure todo items move client and messages outside of implement more robust server utilities to make implementing protocol servers easier
add candockasdocument to idockable hi i would like to be able to prevent some dockables from being moved to the nearest document currently there is no simple way to disable this functionality

text:
Add Active Play detection service
There's a number of things like focusing on a task, running automation/hack for generating intelligence xp etc. that we don't want to do if the player is actively interacting with the game, but we do want to do them whenever the player has gone away.

We could probably create a service daemon that uses mouse movement and keyboard input events to detect when the player is interacting with the game and when it's been more than a configurable amount of time since any of those events have happened.

Could have some way to configure what scripts to execute or tasks to run when the player is absent.

Privacy for crahalityics I need to updat eprivacy that we allso collect data from crashes. here is the suggestes diff for firebase-hosting\public\privacy.html @@ -

We also collect analytical data and breadcrumbs for analysis purposes in order to improve user experience and eliminate bugs. This includes tracking user interactions, app usage patterns, authentication flows, and tournament participation to help us identify and fix issues.

+

We also collect analytical data and breadcrumbs for analysis purposes in order to improve user experience and eliminate bugs. This includes tracking user interactions, app usage patterns, authentication flows, and tournament participation to help us identify and fix issues.

+

Additionally, the app uses Google Analytics for Firebase (GA4) and Firebase Crashlytics. GA4 helps us understand how users engage with the app, while Crashlytics collects crash reports and diagnostic data (such as device type, operating system, app version, and crash details) to help us improve stability and fix problems. These services are provided by Google LLC in accordance with their Privacy Policy.

Issue with login via facebook
WHen i build the app locally using _prodDebug flavor, it logs to facebook without any issues, see logcat below:

2025-09-01 09:08:17.573 19408-19408 TAG_Soccer              piotr_gorczynski.soccer2             D  UniversalLoginActivity.handleProviderLogin: Provider selected = facebook.com
2025-09-01 09:08:17.580 19408-19408 TAG_Soccer              piotr_gorczynski.soccer2             D  UniversalLoginActivity.handleProviderLogin: Calling authManager.loginWithProvider
2025-09-01 09:08:28.469 19408-19408 TAG_Soccer              piotr_gorczynski.soccer2             D  SoccerApp.cancelHeartbeat: Cancelling WorkManager
2025-09-01 09:08:28.486 19408-19408 TAG_Soccer              piotr_gorczynski.soccer2             D  FirebaseAuthManager.loginWithFacebookToken: signInWithCredential success


but when i compile the _prodRelease flavor, and try to login via facebook, following error is thrown via facebook:

Invalid key hash. The key hash
[REDACTED KEY HASH]
does not match any stored key hashes. Configure your app key hashes at
https://developers.facebook.com/apps/[REDACTED APP ID]

I check and [REDACTED APP ID] matches the one configured on facebook and [REDACTED KEY HASH] is also configured on facebook.

FIx it or tell me how to fix it.

in the GOOGLE_PLAY_RELEASE_NOTES_v10.0.txt and RELEASE_NOTES_v10.0.md it is written that New Multi-Language Support was introduced. That is is not true. It was introduced in the former version. Remove it from all describtions in these two files in all languagages.

Updat the version of the file fom 10 to 11

clean: documentdock close lables invalid with tabslayout left when the is set to left or right the labels should say close all tabs above instead of left img width 604 height 581 alt image src

crashes on production after release 11 was published on production a number of crashes occured with following error piotr gorczynski soccer2 issue df5177165afe47cde6248a142d5ada39 crash session 68b69e31013500016b0cfa93ae82feff dne 0 v2 stacktrace txt gemini analysis from firebase crashlitycs is following the badtokenexception with the message unable to add window token android os binderproxy is not valid is your activity running indicates that the application is trying to display a window like a dialog toast snackbar or a custom view added to windowmanager using a window token that is no longer valid cause of the issue a window token is typically tied to the lifecycle of an activity or a service when an activity is destroyed or no longer in the foreground its associated window token becomes invalid if the application attempts to show a window using this invalid token the badtokenexception is thrown in this specific case piotr gorczynski soccer2 inappmessaginghelper showversiontargetedmessage is likely attempting to display some form of in app message if this method is called after the activity that provided the context for the window token has been destroyed or put in the background the exception occurs this often happens in asynchronous operations where a callback tries to display ui elements after the original ui context is gone debugging and resolution identify the ui element being displayed examine the showversiontargetedmessage method within inappmessaginghelper java determine exactly what ui element it is attempting to display e g alertdialog toast snackbar popupwindow or a custom view added via windowmanager trace the call to showversiontargetedmessage find all locations in your codebase where showversiontargetedmessage is called investigate the lifecycle state of the activity or context that is passed to this method or used internally by inappmessaginghelper at the time of the call reproduce the crash if not easily reproducible if the crash is intermittent try to simulate scenarios where an activity is quickly destroyed or backgrounded while showversiontargetedmessage might be pending execution examples navigating away from an activity rapidly pressing the back button rotating the device which destroys and recreates the activity moving the app to the background and then bringing it back to the foreground actionable next step implement lifecycle aware ui updates before attempting to show any ui element check if the associated activity is still active and not finishing best practices to avoid this issue use activity isfinishing or activity isdestroyed before displaying any ui element that requires an activity context always check if the activity is finishing or has been destroyed example for a dialog if activity null activity isfinishing activity isdestroyed show the dialog dialog show expand apply this check within or around the showversiontargetedmessage method if inappmessaginghelper takes a context ensure it s an activity context when ui elements are being displayed and perform the check leverage androidx lifecycle components if you re using androidx you can make your ui updates lifecycle aware by observing the lifecycle of an activity or fragment this is particularly useful for asynchronous operations pass a lifecycleowner like an activity or fragment to your helper class register a lifecycleobserver in your helper class or within a livedata observer in your activity inappmessaginghelper getinstance showversiontargetedmessage this getlifecycle in inappmessaginghelper public void showversiontargetedmessage context context lifecycle lifecycle if lifecycle getcurrentstate isatleast lifecycle state resumed or at least started depending on when you want to show it ensure the context is an activity if context instanceof activity activity activity activity context if activity isfinishing activity isdestroyed show your message e g dialog show else defer the message or cancel if the state is not suitable example add a lifecycleobserver to show it when resumed lifecycle addobserver new lifecycleobserver onlifecycleevent lifecycle event on resume public void onresume if context instanceof activity activity activity activity context if activity isfinishing activity isdestroyed show your message lifecycle removeobserver this remove once shown or if no longer needed expand handle asynchronous callbacks if showversiontargetedmessage is called from an asynchronous callback e g network response timer ensure the context is still valid at the time the callback executes the lifecycle aware approach is the most robust solution for this use application context for certain ui elements for toast messages you can often use application context instead of activity context however this is generally not suitable for dialogs or complex views that require a theme or specific window management as they need an activity context using application context for a dialog will likely lead to a different badtokenexception or visual inconsistencies in this case inappmessaginghelper is probably trying to show something more complex than a toast

text:
Back button

text:
Consent fix
Google Analytics is showing following information:

Consent missing for EEA users
Your Google Analytics for Firebase SDK isn’t sending consent information from end users in the European Economic Area (EEA), which may impact ads personalisation and measurement. To fix this, set up consent mode.

Codex suggested:

You’ll need to update your application code, not Google Analytics settings.

Google Analytics for Firebase expects the app to send explicit consent information for EEA users. Currently, your app isn’t supplying it, so Analytics can’t personalize or measure ads.

What to do:

Integrate a consent-gathering flow (e.g., Google’s User Messaging Platform or your own CMP).

Once the user responds, call the Firebase Analytics consent APIs to pass their choice (e.g., setConsent or setAnalyticsCollectionEnabled).

For web, you’d use gtag or Google Tag Manager to set analytics_storage, ad_storage, etc., after consent is known. For mobile apps, use the appropriate Firebase SDK methods.

There’s no toggle in the Google Analytics UI that resolves this—it must be handled in code so EEA users’ consent is collected and sent before Analytics/Ads functionality is enabled.


so i would like to use Google’s User Messaging Platform to collect relevant consent.

Be aware that we already collect consent for AdMOb.

text:
UNiversal login fix
When user in mobile/app/src/main/java/piotr_gorczynski/soccer2/UniversalLoginActivity.java is pressing button related to login via google or facebook or anonymous, very often another provide windows is open and loging process is executed. Meanwhile the buttons are stil active and unpatient user can press again login button via facebook, gmail or anonymous, which can cause issues. Therefore fix it somehow that until the login process with the provider is not finalized either with success or failure, the butoons should be disabled and some toast can be shown - we can use <string name="registration_in_progress">Registration attempt in progress…</string>

text:
Consider how to make Discover subscriptions more type-safe
The change to defining the basic sending messages entirely inside `defineProtocol` means that the Discover service needs to manually construct and send request envelopes and they are completely unchecked on the client side.

This works but is a clear end-run around the type-safety and security we've built with the protocol abstraction, and it would be nice to do this more cleanly.

One possibility, since I think it should be possible to read from multiple ports as long as we don't race `port.nextWrite` promises against each other. We could change the way Discover subscriptions work.

There could be some kind of well-known port where Discover publishes the known worker and target hosts.

This could be as simple as a port for each type, and the Discover service writes the list of all hosts of that type as a message. Then consumers can read the current list there, and receive updates when the list changes. The Discover service would pop the current message from the queue after writing an updated message each time.

Or we could build some kind of pub-sub abstraction? Or we could use Sodium streams? Of all the options I think I like Sodium streams the best.
clean: consider how to make discover subscriptions more type safe the change to defining the basic sending messages entirely inside means that the discover service needs to manually construct and send request envelopes and they are completely unchecked on the client side this works but is a clear end run around the type safety and security we ve built with the protocol abstraction and it would be nice to do this more cleanly one possibility since i think it should be possible to read from multiple ports as long as we don t race promises against each other we could change the way discover subscriptions work there could be some kind of well known port where discover publishes the known worker and target hosts this could be as simple as a port for each type and the discover service writes the list of all hosts of that type as a message then consumers can read the current list there and receive updates when the list changes the discover service would pop the current message from the queue after writing an updated message each time or we could build some kind of pub sub abstraction or we could use sodium streams of all the options i think i like sodium streams the best

text:
Use new channel API in Dispatch service so we can return Netscript promises to client code
Currently the dispatcher `await`s the result of calling the resolved Netscript function. This means that if client code calls a Netscript API that blocks for an extended period of time (like `ns.grafting.waitForOngoingGrafting` then the dispatch service could be unavailable for up to an hour of real time!

To solve this without some kind of forking process, we should move away from using Netscript ports for the Dispatch service and instead use our new `Channel` utility so we can return promises to the client.
clean: use new channel api in dispatch service so we can return netscript promises to client code currently the dispatcher s the result of calling the resolved netscript function this means that if client code calls a netscript api that blocks for an extended period of time like then the dispatch service could be unavailable for up to an hour of real time to solve this without some kind of forking process we should move away from using netscript ports for the dispatch service and instead use our new utility so we can return promises to the client

text:
Enhance dispatch init script to be a Supervisor for the dispatch executor
Based on discussion here: https://chatgpt.com/share/68bb8c95-5548-8001-9fc5-7e6818301518
clean: enhance dispatch init script to be a supervisor for the dispatch executor based on discussion here

text:
Improve task selector target prioritization
Currently we just hack all targets in hack level order. This is simple but definitely sub-optimal for quick progress and high profits.

A better heuristic would be to filter by scripts needing `hackLevel < 50%` and then sort by the largest grow factor.

We could also use the expected value per ram second which should take this grow factor into account when calculating the number of grow threads for a batch.

text:
Change NS import to be `@ns` instead of `netscript`
It seems to be what most of the tooling has standardized on so it will make my scripts more shareable with people.

text:
Create a user activity detection service
There are some tasks that I want to run in the background if I'm not actively doing anything with the game, like intelligence farming, but I don't want them to aggressively prevent me from using the UI if I am doing something.

More importantly, I want these scripts to be able to detect when I walk away from the game without setting them up and automatically start.

Some useful resources for implementing this:

- [a potential library to vendor and use](https://github.com/tuenti/activity-detector/blob/master/src/activity-detector.js)
- [a web API for extra processing time notification](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/requestIdleCallback)
- [a mdn Guide on using that API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Background_Tasks_API)

text:
Create a custom shell to run in launch service daemon UI
As I'm using my terminal automation utility more, I'm finding that it's quite useful to have something automatic happening in the terminal most of the time. I often find myself killing that script just to run a single script or two for testing or similar and then restarting it. This is precisely what my launch script is for though.

I originally wanted to add a "higher-order" shell command to launch scripts with my launcher service, but I stalled out on trying to get seamless usage of the autocomplete API.

If we implemented a custom terminal in the log view of our launcher script we could do argument parsing how we want to and potentially provide a better autocomplete experience.

We could also reimplement a bunch of the basic shell utilities as builtins, and as a bonus make them work across all hosts!

For most things I could basically follow Phil Nelson's minishell assignments.

## Autocomplete

Without the `dynamicImport` API coming in 3.0 autocomplete will be annoying to implement. But we can probably hack it together. Something like:
 - dynamically generate a script that statically imports the script the user is launching
 - exec that script with `ramOverride` because we only import the autocomplete function
 - communicate with the generated script via ports/channels to get autocompletion results from the function

Which will all be much, much simpler in 3.0.

## Stretch goals:

- Shell scripting for lightweight automation

text:
Create a logging-facade + React UI utility
The logging side panel that Codex created for me for the memory allocator service is useful but now that we render React components once and then update their state, we can do a lot better.

In particular, we can create a page flip thing where we have the default view be the custom UI and have a toggle button in the corner that let's the user switch to the log view.

Stretch version would include supporting displaying logs side-by-side or in the button selected "tab view" mode, both by default in the API and at runtime by the user.

We would also want to make a cleaner UI monkey-patch that intercepts the logging messages.

Not sure exactly how well it would work to actually monkey-patch the Netscript API object and override the `print` and `printf` functions. Maybe even the `printRaw` one? That's definitely a stretch goal.

text:
Use stricter typescript options
This is probably going to be a big project. We should enable stricter typescript checking, specifically:

- strict null checks


Something like this (from the [Typescript Documentation on choosing compiler settings](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/modules/guides/choosing-compiler-options.html#im-writing-a-library)):

```json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "module": "esnext",
    "target": "esnext", // set to the *lowest* target you support
    "strict": true,
    "verbatimModuleSyntax": true,
    "declaration": true,
    "sourceMap": true,
    "declarationMap": true,
    "rootDir": "src",
    "outDir": "dist"
  }
}
```

We'll need to verify each of these settings makes sense for our project.

text:
Think about switching build infrastructure to Viteburner
Looks like [Viteburner] is a pretty popular tool for uploading scripts from an external typescript project. It's probably worth taking a deeper look at what it would look like to set it up to compile our code.

[Viteburner]: https://github.com/Tanimodori/viteburner/blob/main/docs/guide/quick-start.md

Changing the terminal command to wait forever for the terminal to come back (in #300) means that scripts just keep running so this doesn't necessarily make sense anymore.

The real fix for this is not chaining too many commands at once. Since a failure executing a command rejects the promise returned to the API client it should crash that script.

Maybe implementing command chaining with `;`s was a mistake because that's the only case that can be an error really.

text:
Refactors before switching to channels
To make this hard change easier:

- [ ] Hide port usage, push channel allocation inside `BaseServer` and `BaseClient` constructors.
- [ ] Refactor port consuming loops to happen in one method (`awaxt nextWrite` & `for all messages`)
  * [ ] `BaseServer`
  * [ ] `GrowableMemoryClient`
  * [ ] `DispatchServer`
- [ ] Split refactor into two parts
  * [ ] Switch from `NetscriptPort` to `Channel`
  * [ ] Switch from request/response Ports and message IDs to individual ports for responses???
- [ ] Refactor `DispatchServer` to be restarted by `DispatchSupervisor`
- [ ] Make `DispatchServer` have some form of persistent ID assigned by `DispatchSupervisor`


First we want to minimize the number of places that a `NetscriptPort` appears in a public API.

For the loop refactor, we want to more closely model how looping over a channel works. Have one function for doing the looping, one function for processing a single message from the channel.

Finally, we need to make the dispatch script more robust in the face of not being able to leave messages on the port until it's ready to deal with them, and in general it needs to be able to have multiple instances of the server running at the same time without stepping on each other's toes. This basically means no `peeking` at the port, and this forces us to have a restart mechanism that can store the message.

Ugh, maybe I need to implement a mode on the `Channel` so that it can behave as a true broadcast channel where every consumer receives every message sent!

Okay, as inconvenient as Bitburner's port API is, perhaps its the best solution for a difficult problem of providing a complex API to potentially inexperienced users...

text:
Maybe we want the `DispatchSupervisor` to act like a traffic router as well then? While trying to switch from using `NetscriptPort` to our new `Channel` API I ran into an interesting consequence of not having a `peek` method on the channel.

If we don't have a peek method, then we need to store messages that have been popped from the queue that we can't handle. But this becomes another shared queue, now with a peek method. If all `DispatchServer` instances are prioritizing reading from it, then one large RAM request could cause all of them to restart in rapid succession as they each try to read it from the queue.

Multiple consumers is actually kind of a hard problem!

So instead, maybe what we need to do is shift the problem. If we made the `DispatchSupervisor`, (or perhaps a third component, `DispatchLoadBalancer`?) responsible for reading from the queue and then forwarding the message to the appropriate `DispatchServer` instance, then this script could hold a queue for each `DispatchServer` instance and send a restart message on the channel it holds to communicate with that instance. This would also open the door to making each instance specialize in commands of a certain size range, or prioritizing sending message requests that an instance has already seen to it so it doesn't have to restart.

text:
Consider how to make channel usage safer for Netscript scripts
Writing Netscript scripts that do async things and properly shutdown when the "script" is "killed" is tricky, and the further away from using Netscript APIs you go, the murkier the waters get.

Netscript Ports are already a bit of a pitfall in regards to leaving scripts potentially hanging as I saw when implementing my dispatch server.

My new async `Channel` class might have serious problems with presenting an ergonomic API and also not leaking a bunch of memory/tasks when scripts are shutdown.

Consider a relatively straightforward scenario of a daemon script reading from it's channel. In order to actually stop the reading loop the server will need to create an `AbortController` and register an `ns.atExit` callback that signals abort and pass this signal in to the `Channel.readAll` method.

I could include a wrapper method that does that, but now I'm bring an NS API into the mix.

The same thing is true for any script that wants to block on writing to a `Channel`. Thats' a lot of boilerplate if I include it everywhere, or writing wrapper methods, or including the `nsAtExitFixture` in the channel tests and baking it into the API.

The last option is definitely the most ergonomic option from the consumer perspective and it doesn't really make sense to create a channel class and then immediately create a netscript wrapper for it when I'm not trying to create a general-purpose library.

Should I even be creating my own channel class in the first place? Is that really what I want to be writing? I'm definitely learning things from it...

text:
Figure out how to handle closed channels in the ports map
The idea of closing a channel is very foreign to code working with NetscriptPorts because they simply cannot ever be closed.

This makes sense from a lot of perspectives. Ports are a global resource accessed by index, a closed port in the global index is... what? just dead forever? That doesn't make sense.

When should you close a port, when the script exits? But you're probably just going to restart that script with a newer version. If you don't want to receive stale messages you just run clear and empty the buffer.

The idea of truly async ports sounded fantastic at first, but the deeper I go down this rabbithole, the more I realize I'm in Wonderland and the Javascript VM is a truly strange beast that I only barely grasp the barest hints of.

Probably the right solution here is to get rid of the `Channel.close` API entirely. Not much of a loss really.

text:
Instead of just wrapping the module as a Service with a message protocol, we could expand the scope to actually do target prioritization/ranking, separate from the actual task spawning of the task selector. It would depend on the target events from the Discovery service, augment them with the expect value for hacking with current RAM and then publish a sorted list according to maximum expected value per RAM second.

Open question is on how to deal with killing jobs to reclaim memory.

text:
Experiment with "zero-delay" shotgun batching
I read old resources on implementing batch hacking. The current advice is to implement a shotgun batcher with zero delays between batches and just spawn as many batches as possible against the best target.

We should definitely try this strategy along with more precise timing calculation by calculating the ending time relative to `performance.now` and letting each spawned h/g/w helper script calculate the amount of additional time needed to end at the goal time (as described in #211).

text:
Change startup to be more modular and based on Sodium Streams
Always start the core services like memory, port, launcher and reset info (replace source-file service).

Other services should be started on-demand by registering a script launch command. These script launching commands should include the script name, optional launch options, and a set of source file level dependencies. Or, perhaps we could write another script scanner function like the dependency gatherer to determine which NS APIs the script uses and thus what source files (or levels) it requires.

Actually, we want to be able to register multiple scripts, or perhaps the same script with different arguments and dynamic RAM settings to turn off usage of any features which aren't available.

This will really open the door to writing scripts that take advantage of APIs from different bitnodes.

The only other problem is how to name them. Currently most of the restricted APIs are in their own folders, but having conceptual folders that focus on solving a mechanic like hacking probably make more sense.

text:
Sodium based message protocol
Wild half-asleep idea for how to structure a buffering protocol using Sodium `Stream` and `Cell`. Sending a message is sending to a published Sodium `Stream` somehow (`StreamSink`?). This `Stream` accumulates into a `Cell<Immutable.List<Message>>`.

The "server" daemon drains the buffer via sending an event that snapshots the message `Cell`, and updates the Cell to a new empty list. This event will "carry" the current buffer of messages to the listener in the server for it to process.

For performance we could treat this as a single abstraction implemented by two cooperating cells, like the amortized fast queue implementation done with two stacks (head and tail). When the head stack is empty, you flip the tail stack over into the head stack. In our case, using immutable-js persistent data structures we can implement the tail with an `Immutable.List`, and the tail is a `Immutable.Seq` over the previous tail. This could be inefficient if it's one message at a time, maybe? Need to benchmark or something?

This would allow for sending messages to a service before it is started, similar to how we can with `NetscriptPort`s.

Responses can be achieved by including a promise resolving function in the message.

text:
Fix React hooks cleanup function
Replacing the `ns.atExit` function throws an error when closing a scripts tail window. It's good when we close a tail window while the script is running, but if the script has already been killed then the `ns.atExit` access will throw. This isn't really an issue because the `atExit` handler will have already stopped the polling interval, but the error is still spam in the console.

text:
Implement a hashed timing wheel (like Tokio) for precise timers
Add an API that allows precise timing of events by returning Promises that resolve when that timer has elapsed.

Internally, we can have 1 task running a timing tick that moves forward a hashed timing wheel like Tokio has implemented.

We can use a combination of conservative sleep timers, running when the browser has time for it, and wake-ups when new timers are registered to keep the performance impact of this API low.
clean: implement a hashed timing wheel like tokio for precise timers add an api that allows precise timing of events by returning promises that resolve when that timer has elapsed internally we can have 1 task running a timing tick that moves forward a hashed timing wheel like tokio has implemented we can use a combination of conservative sleep timers running when the browser has time for it and wake ups when new timers are registered to keep the performance impact of this api low

text: A precise timer like this should make it much easier to implement a JIT batcher.
clean: a precise timer like this should make it much easier to implement a jit batcher

text:
Sodium ApiCell caches data for too long
Since the `Cell` essentially caches data in memory indefinitely, when we do things like install augmentations, soft reset or finish a Bitnode these caches will become out of date. Currently, the start script is failing because the Discovery service values are cached and the cache is never cleared.

We can add a method to clear this cached value, and we can clear the cache when the provider script starts, however this feels a bit like going in the wrong direction.

Another possibility might be to create a Sodium proxy for the NS API. These wrappers could send events to public Streams. The tricky thing about this is that it means that every script should probably be using this wrapper, that means that a _lot_ of different streams are going to be connecting to these public APIs.

It would be much better to try to install a hook into the game internals in the appropriate spot to emit an event for the appropriate moments.
clean: sodium apicell caches data for too long since the essentially caches data in memory indefinitely when we do things like install augmentations soft reset or finish a bitnode these caches will become out of date currently the start script is failing because the discovery service values are cached and the cache is never cleared we can add a method to clear this cached value and we can clear the cache when the provider script starts however this feels a bit like going in the wrong direction another possibility might be to create a sodium proxy for the ns api these wrappers could send events to public streams the tricky thing about this is that it means that every script should probably be using this wrapper that means that a lot of different streams are going to be connecting to these public apis it would be much better to try to install a hook into the game internals in the appropriate spot to emit an event for the appropriate moments

text:
Create a Sodium NS proxy API
It might be useful to create a Sodium proxy for parts of the NS API. These wrappers could send events to public `ApiStream`s. The tricky thing about this is that it means that every script should probably be using this wrapper, that means that a lot of different streams are going to be connecting to these public APIs.

It would be much better to try to install a hook into the game internals in the appropriate spot to emit an event for the appropriate moments.

Some useful events I can think of:

- Bitnode Start
- Soft reset
- Augmentations installed
- Bitnode reset
clean: create a sodium ns proxy api it might be useful to create a sodium proxy for parts of the ns api these wrappers could send events to public s the tricky thing about this is that it means that every script should probably be using this wrapper that means that a lot of different streams are going to be connecting to these public apis it would be much better to try to install a hook into the game internals in the appropriate spot to emit an event for the appropriate moments some useful events i can think of bitnode start soft reset augmentations installed bitnode reset

text:
Rewrite Port Allocator service in Sodium
The Port Allocator process actually doesn't consult the Netscript API at all. We can probably make it independent of the starter script by implementing purely in Sodium.

The "service" aspect of it would then be basically just the UI.

The only question about implementing it is if we can make a "response" for the allocation in a reasonable way. I'm not sure if the Sodium API has a "listen once" method. We want to ensure that if multiple clients request a port number they will receive unique responses.
clean: rewrite port allocator service in sodium the port allocator process actually doesn t consult the netscript api at all we can probably make it independent of the starter script by implementing purely in sodium the service aspect of it would then be basically just the ui the only question about implementing it is if we can make a response for the allocation in a reasonable way i m not sure if the sodium api has a listen once method we want to ensure that if multiple clients request a port number they will receive unique responses

text:
Config Freeze
Switching to a new Bitburner app instance or browser means that I lose the LocalStorage configs I've tuned. Trying to diff the config and copy it over is silly, so it would be nice if there was a facility to save the current config as a file, and then reload it in a new browser. Since the file will be saved as part of the Bitburner save export this would allow nicely transferring to the new machine.

It also might be useful to have a facility for updating the default values in the actual Config definitions because if I've left a config alone for very long that's probably what I want it to be in general.

text:
You missed invite notification
When user activates app, it should check - providing that the system is not offline - if user received since last moment when he was using the app an invitation, which he didn't accepted. Then popup should be shown saying you received an invitation while you were off  and it should offer to choices: see invites or close. If user chooses see invites, then pending invites activity should be open. If close, the popup should just close.
Remember to translate strings to all supported languages in strings.

text:
Refresh Wins
Consider scenario:
1. user A is on mobile/app/src/main/java/piotr_gorczynski/soccer2/FriendsListActivity.java
2. he invites another user, lets say B for a game and he is redirected to WaitingActivity
3. The game is accepted and he enters gameActivity
4. Suppose USer A wins
5. User is redirected back to screen FriendsListActivity.java
6. The infromation about that inite was sent from user A to B is refreshed on the screen but infromation that user A won the game is not refreshed
clean: refresh wins consider scenario 1 user a is on mobile 2 he invites another user lets say b for a game and he is redirected to waitingactivity 3 the game is accepted and he enters gameactivity 4 suppose user a wins 5 user is redirected back to screen friendslistactivity java 6 the infromation about that inite was sent from user a to b is refreshed on the screen but infromation that user a won the game is not refreshed

text:
INvitations list
When mobile/app/src/main/java/piotr_gorczynski/soccer2/InvitationsActivity.java is opened, it does not show all invitations, only part of them.

SO i want to have explicitely paginated list, which will show button "Load more" or osmething, that will enalbe loading the remaining invitations.|

Remeber taht we should have already "Load more" string and it should be translated to all supported languages.

text:
Fix bootstrap generation
There are currently several issues with the bootstrap script:
clean: fix bootstrap generation there are currently several issues with the bootstrap script

text:
Build doesn't capture nested folders
It looks like the way I generate the build zip file only handles one level of folders, so nested folders aren't included.

Specifically, this line from the `build.yml` workflow:

```
- name: Package output
if: github.ref_type == 'tag'
run: zip ${{ env.ARTIFACT_FILE }} dist/**/*.js dist/*.js
```

This should be changed to make zip capture everything in `dist/` recursively.
clean: build doesn t capture nested folders it looks like the way i generate the build zip file only handles one level of folders so nested folders aren t included specifically this line from the workflow this should be changed to make zip capture everything in recursively

text:
Bootstrap file includes paths that have been deleted
Currently the bootstrap script is generated during build. The latest run of the bootstrap has entries for files that 404 when fetching from github.

Specifically, these files:

- `buy-hacknet.js`
- `jest-shim.js`
- `batch/lib.js`
- `batch/leak-check.js`
- `batch/worker.js`

These look like files that have been deleted or moved, and `jest-shim.js` just shouldn't be included at all.
clean: bootstrap file includes paths that have been deleted currently the bootstrap script is generated during build the latest run of the bootstrap has entries for files that 404 when fetching from github specifically these files these look like files that have been deleted or moved and just shouldn t be included at all

text:
Using an old bootstrap.js after a new release is almost guaranteed to fail
There's a mismatch in the bootstrap system where we create a frozen snapshot of the list of files in a given release, but then we pull files from the `latest-files` branch. If a new release is created between the time someone downloads the bootstrap file and when they run it, this will almost certainly result in downloading an incomplete version of the newest release, instead of a complete version of the one they tried to download.
clean: using an old bootstrap js after a new release is almost guaranteed to fail there s a mismatch in the bootstrap system where we create a frozen snapshot of the list of files in a given release but then we pull files from the branch if a new release is created between the time someone downloads the bootstrap file and when they run it this will almost certainly result in downloading an incomplete version of the newest release instead of a complete version of the one they tried to download

text:
Improve bootstrap UX
Currently, because the bootstrap uses `ns.wget` it is extremely slow and it takes a while to complete, with no visual feedback for the user. We should at least improve the experience by displaying some information.

- [ ] Console message when starting and finishing bootstrap
- [ ] Open tail window and display a progress bar of total files downloaded
- [ ] Add some cute ASCII art or something to keep them entertained maybe?
clean: improve bootstrap ux currently because the bootstrap uses it is extremely slow and it takes a while to complete with no visual feedback for the user we should at least improve the experience by displaying some information console message when starting and finishing bootstrap open tail window and display a progress bar of total files downloaded add some cute ascii art or something to keep them entertained maybe

Best user experience for showing hand
in #744 we added hand and it works perfectly.

Now i am thinking about best user experience to show such guidance.

Maybe w e caan show dialog after 3 cycles with the following message "do uou still want me to show you possible moves? You can always tuni it off and on in Setings"

if user answers yes, then increase number of cycles to 10 and then ask again, if user still sya yes, ask again after 20 cycles. Remener that this counter must be kept outside the games, because gmes might finish earlier.

If user say no., stop showing the hand and remeber thsi choise in settings.

SO in seeting add additional menu posistion like "SHow with hand possible moves" and by defauly it should be ON, when application starts.

text:
service account
The gcp\cloud-build\grant_vertex_ai_user_to_appengine_sa.yaml grants credentials to appengine_sa="${project_id}@appspot.gserviceaccount.com" (effectively it was reolved to 
soccer-dev-1744877837@appspot.gserviceaccount.com

but the way the gcp\cloud-build\deploy_check_nickname.yaml deploys function causes, that i found that the function is using  491861032786-compute@developer.gserviceaccount.com 


in order to get this name i tested and in gcli this works:

admin_@cloudshell:~ (soccer-dev-1744877837)$ gcloud run services describe checknickname     --region us-central1     --format 'value(spec.template.spec.serviceAccountName)'
491861032786-compute@developer.gserviceaccount.com
admin_@cloudshell:~ (soccer-dev-1744877837)$ 

so i suggest  in grant_vertex_ai_user_to_appengine_sa.yaml
you add logic to get this name service account name and grants it the proer role
clean: service account the gcp cloud build grant vertex ai user to appengine sa yaml grants credentials to appengine sa project id appspot gserviceaccount com effectively it was reolved to soccer dev appspot gserviceaccount com but the way the gcp cloud build deploy check nickname yaml deploys function causes that i found that the function is using compute developer gserviceaccount com in order to get this name i tested and in gcli this works admin cloudshell soccer dev gcloud run services describe checknickname region us central1 format value spec template spec serviceaccountname compute developer gserviceaccount com admin cloudshell soccer dev so i suggest in grant vertex ai user to appengine sa yaml you add logic to get this name service account name and grants it the proer role

text:
roles/serviceusage.serviceUsageConsumer
modify gcp\cloud-build\grant_vertex_ai_user_to_appengine_sa.yaml to grant role roles/serviceusage.serviceUsageConsumer to this service account

text:
Add animation of kikcing soccer player
There is a mobile/app/src/main/java/piotr_gorczynski/soccer2/RunPlayerSprite.java which corresponds to mobile/app/src/main/res/drawable/spritesheet_run.png.

I want you to add new class KickPlayerSprite.java, whcih should correspond to mobile/app/src/main/res/drawable/spritesheet_kick.png.
The number of frames in this animation is 16, the remaining parameters are the same as for RunPlayerSprite.java.

After you add this animation I want you to change how animation works. 
In the scenario that playerX where X={0,1} is making a move, the sprite from RunPlayerSprite animation is used. I want you for this and only this scenario play first animation using sprite from KickPlayerSprite and then immediately RunPlayerSprite .

Be aware that for the other player, the animation remains the same i.e. using sprite from RunPlayerSprite.

@copilot The #851  improved situation but not entirly.
I will describe the residual issue :

Let's assume it is player0 turn. Before the move is made, the sprite of player0 stands at player0 position, and sprite of player 1 stands te player1 position.

Then user makes a move for player 0.

The player1 sprite is shifted from former position to the ball position - THIS IS INCORRECT. The sprite of player 1 should continue to stay at the same position. So fix it. Only when player0 finishes kick animation , the player 1 sprite should start running, 

The bahvaiour and logic and animation for player0 are working correctly - THIS IS CORRECT!

text:
Fix animation
@copilot latest #852  has not fixed the issue.
I will describe the issue again:

Let's assume it is player0 turn. Before the move is made, the sprite of player0 stands at player0 position lets call it (x0,y0), and sprite of player 1 stands te player1 position lets call it (x1,y1).

Then user makes a move for player 0.

The player1 sprite is shifted from former position (x1,y1) to the ball position lets call it (x_ball,y_ball)- THIS IS INCORRECT. The sprite of player 1 should continue to stay at the same position (x1,y1) . So fix it.
